Posted: September 6, 2014
												On the bright side, it's an undying classic, which provides a strong foundation for the series. Radiating that unique halo of the Warhammer 40K franchise, it appeals to any fan tremendously, while still holding a certain entertainment value to a complete stranger, too. Concerning campaign, the plot is traditionally brutal and somewhat enigmatic, and the roleplaying aspect is rather decent for an RTS. In two words, there are Space Marines, and their famous Tartarus campaign (with Imperial Guard cameo, sort of). Concerning skirmish, the tech-trees are quite clear, and the resource management is pretty straightforward. The game is about battle tactics and strategies, and in this field it delivers fairly deep and dynamic experience. In skirmish, Orks, Eldar, and Chaos factions are all playable, too. And re-playable, and enjoyable, of course.Talking cons, the textures and video FX are so... oldschool, and the music is rather naive to my taste. Besides, the in-game tooltip fonts are so small that it's almost unreadable, and also unscalable, just like this Steam's built-in browser. But the most annoying thing in the whole game is the dumbest pathfinding ever, which makes fielding large armies quite a challenge. See, the map landscape is typically uneven here, the terrain is rough, and the ruins are everywhere (supposed to be tactical, I think). That doesn't work well with bad pathfinding, - when you issue a move order for several squads at once, you can see them crowding, loosing formations, getting stuck, holding each other, then running away or apart from each other, and begging to be shot during all the hilarious process. Now, THAT is not something to which you can accomodate, not after playing so many modern RTS with brilliant pathfinding. That's why, against modern standards (e.g. DoW II), the game is a bit too uncomfortable to play on a regular basis.Verdict: definitely a "must have" for the fans of Warhammer 40K universe, and well recommended for the students of classic RTS. For everybody else - it's your call, but I'd recommend starting with DoW II instead.

Posted: May 16, 2013
												Just like the other 885,363 PC gamers out there, a few weeks ago I picked up a copy of the Humble THQ Bundle. Not only was it a great deal for some games, it was also a way to help a company in need.  Now everyone can argue the ‘Hows’ and ‘Whys’ of THQ’s current situation, but at the end of the day gamers aren’t overly interested in their products.  And its hurting them more than it has in years.  But this isn’t an financial overview of the current fiscal situation of THQ.This is a Bargain Bin Breakdown, and the game is Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War.  And you may have figured out prior to the break that I’ve never played anything Warhammer 40,000 before.  So its another unbiased review that falls completely on the games merit!  I love it when that happens.  However, with schedules tightening and life being life, I’m not always able to play an entire game.  Its actually a difficult choice on what to play when and for how long.  And having nine new games added to my Steam games list only makes it more of a challenge.  Do you realize I’ve had L.A. Noire for months and have yet to play it?!But I’m rambling again…My plan with Dawn of War was to play at least 3 missions of the main campaign then a skirmish as the enemy faction.  This, in theory, would give me enough to rate the games mechanics, story, and balance.  After which point I could continue to play, if the game had captured my interest, or begin writing my review.  Everything started well.  I played the tutorial so I could see which type of RTS this was.  Then I started the first mission.I was impressed at how well they tell the story with the opening sequences.  Even if I wasn’t really following what was going on with the story, the way in which it was given was very well done.  Unfortunately, to me its just another Orc vs Human story that I can’t find interest in.And unfortunately I've never had any interest into the types of worlds where Orcs are present.  I am a fan of Science Fiction, but Fantasy hasn't ever done it for me.  Orcs, Elves, Humans, Middle Earth, whatever or where ever it is, hasn't been my thing.  I've played the WarCraft games, I’ve seen the Lord of the Rings movies, I attempted to read a few different stories in the past.  But none of it really sparks much interest in me.  So the real challenge with games of this genre is to excite me in other ways.  Which has happened, but is a rare occurrence.I can’t find any of the Orcs terrifying, or anything other than plain stupid, and in this game its no different, they just look goofy.  Sure the graphics are dated, but not so bad, and I kinda enjoyed them since they reminded me of Star Wars Galaxies.  But the models themselves, and the designs that were chosen.  A part of my lack of interest in the fantasy worlds fall under technology.  The worlds always look very similar to the Middle Ages, but then there will be some sort of advanced technology that just doesn't fit.The Humans are actually fine in this regard since everything of theirs looks and matches the advance space faring race type.  However the Ocrs look like a lesser advanced race, until they bust out the battle units.  And I just can’t accept being so far advanced on one side and looking a few centuries behind on the other.But story and setting or not I can still play a game.  So I brushed aside my opinions of the story and played on, enjoying the games itself.  And the mechanics are amazing.  The first mission did a great job of holding my hand and guiding me through the process of playing.  Sure, I had learned a bit from the tutorial, but had quit that about halfway in.  It didn’t take long to finish the mission, and even take a moment to realize that I have genuinely enjoyed playing the game.Then came the second mission.  And while I did enjoy myself for most of it, my enjoyment started to ween.  There came a point in the mission where my troops, just a couple of infantry squads, felt so overpowered.  There wasn’t anything they could’t take out in a matter of seconds.  I expected it to be on the easier side this early in the game, but this was ridiculous.  The hand holding was still there, which wasn’t a big deal, just not really necessary.In between he missions are more story pieces.  And I’m not sure what to call them, since they’re not FMV or cinematic’s   They are scripted sequences that take place on the map itself.  Often before you take over control of the game and start the mission.  It was really well done, and probably my favorite thing out of this game.I did also love the dead units not disappearing from the battlefield.  There’s just something about watching your enemies slain pile up.  It really brings to light just how many souls you’ve taken in your quest for vengeance.Onto the third mission, this is where everything changed.  This is where the game got real.It starts with a pre-built base and units guarding checkpoints.  It starts with you coming under attack.  And the attacks don’t waver.  Now I will offer the chance that I was completely missing some important factoid that makes the mission easier.  But I did try it three separate times.  Each time I was unable to build up or maintain a defense force while also building an attack force.  And after awhile the tanks rolled in, and I hadn’t a chance.That’s when a friend informed me of a Mech unit that was located on the map.  So on the fourth attempt I managed to hold my ground long enough to seek out this unit.  I found it and unlocked the ability to build more of them.  And with these new units I swept through the lands slaughtering all that came in my path.  And completed the mission.But here is the problem.  While on previous missions my infantry units mowed through people and buildings like they were all made of paper, now the enemy has tanks and is mowing through me in the same fashion.  Until I get these Mech units, and it sways back into my favor.  I don’t like this.  This doesn’t feel like balance.  It feels like the scales are swaying back and forth.  One side always has an advantage over the other, its just the who that changes.So I tried a Skirmish, just to see.  A standard 8 team Free For All, where I played as the same faction that I was in the campaign.  It was pretty uneventful, I may have had it on too easy of a difficulty.  But I managed to build a base and maintain my defenses from a few attacks, and then build up my attack force.  Then I sent them out to battle, and they walked right through the enemy like paper…Now, when I play a mission I tend to have double the needed units to succeed, sometimes triple.  I love nothing more than having units in the triple digits.  Dawn of War, like most others of its RTS type, has a population limit.  Sometimes I can work with this, but I always feel like its not enough.But don’t think I’m going to trash this game because of the apparent major change in the difficulty curve from mission two to mission three.  Or because the balance feels to be in constant shift.  Because of what I did play of this game I did enjoy.  A lot of this game I thought was great and pretty ground breaking for its time.  I just can’t create any connection with the characters, units, or setting.But I have no plans to uninstalling or forgetting about Dawn of War, I will keep it there, ready for when I’m ready to come back to it.  But most of all this time spent has shown me where Company of Heroes really came from.  Which seeing as I’ve been obsessed with that game is a great way to open my eyes to its evolution.  Things that I don’t like, or don’t feel like they work in Dawn of War are not present in Company of Heroes.  While other things are expanded on and evolved into better thing

Posted: June 24, 2015
												BLOOD FOR THE BLOOD GOD!!(ThanksBuketIloveyounohomo!!) Warhammer® 40,000: Dawn of War® is a RTS game by Relic, who did all the other (Good?) Warhammer  games, along with Company of Heroes.  The gameplay revolves screaming out SPACE MARINES ADVANCE!! and generally capturing strategeic points, which gives you one of the game's currencies, Requisition points. The other is obtained by building generators, which gives you power. You do this all while being attacked by Orks, Eldar, and Chaos Marines. Luckily for you, you have Space Marines, along with a large arsenal featuring units, weapons, and vehicles. So do all your enemies, however, so you must reach your vehicles and other powerful units to give you the advantage you need, before your foes reach it and start smacking your face with their stuff. Yeah, its pretty awesome.  I highly recommend this game as it features a great campaign along with some suprisingly humorous dialouge(Mainly between Bale and Sindri), along, and multiplayer with a Skirmish mode(Standard RTS fair, select a faction(s) and fight them), and, of course, multiplayer(Each player controls a faction. Who'd want to play Eldar, I have no clue.).  I recommend this game to really, just about anyone. I'm terrible at strategey, but I loved this game. (And remember, Even in death I serve!)

Posted: July 7, 2015
												Played this game like 6-7 years ago and played a lot more than stated by steam.IMO dawn of war is defenitly one of the best RTS games of all time and I reccomend you get the whole franchise.Pros--Large control groups compared to other RTS's of the time, allowing you to control huge amounts of units at once-Great camera system allows you to see the battlefield the way you want to see it withought having to use a completely different set of keys-Training squads instead of individual units makes battles seem more large scale and "war like," compared to other RTS games. -More diverse upgrades than  most RTS games.-COMPATIBLE WITH DARK CRUSADE HYPE-Stunning graphics for its time and since the game is old it will run even on the ♥♥♥♥♥iest of todays computers, bringing fun to all computer gamers :DCons--Multiplayer will♥♥♥♥♥♥on you-My second/third favorite war40k factions are not in the game :( -Resource system is different from almost every other RTS i've ever played and im frankly not a huge fan, although some people enjoy it.-Army painter isn't as in-depth as you would hope, but is still fun to play around with.-Campaign is relatively easy and then has a sudden difficulty spike, which turns off both veterans playing on hard modes and new players trying to learn the game.

Posted: April 16
												Dawn of War is a very special game to me, not only beacause it served as my entry point into the WH40k universe, but also as it cemented my love for strategy games along with its expansions, Warcraft 3, Command & Conquer 3: Tiberium Wars and The Battle for Middle-Earth II back in the day. There may not be ample reasons to play it today, but the campaign delivers an interesting, character driven story with stellar voice acting and writing, and serves as a good entry point for anyone unfamiliar with the series and the universe. The multiplayer is dead, but its very much alive in its Dark Crusade expansion, which I recommend getting as well. You'll just need the original game first to play as four out of the seven races that are playable in Dark Crusade. The fifth race, The Imperial Guard, is obtainable through the Winter Assault expansion, while the last two come with Dark Crusade.Last thing I'd like to mention is the sneaky price increase that happened  somewhere near the end of last year. The price went up from 9.99€ to 12,99€, in what I assume is an attempt to cash in on the still growing popularity of the series now that Dawn of War III is coming out at the end of this month. It still gets heavily discounted during sales so you'll be able to get it for just 3.75€, as opposed to 2.50€, which is how much I paid for it.  Nothing major, but nothing fair either. All in all, Dawn of War is a good game that hasn't aged too badly. There's fun to be had in the game's singleplayer campaign, but other than that there isn't much else to do if you're not planning on getting the expansions  so you could play multiplayer.

Posted: July 20, 2015
												I've got a 75% off coupon for this game, so you can have it for $3.25 US if you hurry. I can't use the coupon, so I'd accept just about any offer.This game is good. It fixes most of the common flaws of the RTS genre (lookin at you, Starcraft). Small, plentiful units are grouped into squads and basic/obvious tasks are handled automatically, so there's less micro-managing/actions-per-second and more actual strategy. It's nice to command troops that aren't totally incompetent. The point-capture-for-resources gameplay is reminiscent of the Battlefield series, and a little bit of an improvement IMHO. Balance is decent but not great, but you're playing it on PC, so mods.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 11, 2015
												There are a lot of RTS games out there and Dawn of War is one of the best of the best. It actually does feel like you're playing the Warhammer 40K tabletop game, except without all of the hassle. While the graphics are lacking nowadays, the gameplay and fun factor are still top-notch. There is base building, but it doesn't require an insane amount of micro-managing like SC2 does, for example. What makes this game so enjoyable to me is that you spend the majority of your time managing your massive army and it's just straight up fun to do.The campaign is OK and worth a single playthrough. Just be prepared for drawn out conversations, overly wordy narration, and some incredibly terrible voice acting (though it does have a particular charm). The meat and potatoes is the multiplayer mode, which you can play against CPU bots or online. In this version of the game you can pick between four factions which include Space Marines, Orks, Eldar and Chaos.Highly recommended.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 10, 2014
												Dawn of War is Warhammer 40K's first Real-Time Strategy game in the collection of Warhammer 40K videogames.  Since there's quite a bit to say, I'm just going to categorize the different sections of the game.-Story:  Combining aspects of fantasy and science fiction, you are tasked to lead Gabriel Angelos and the Space Marines known as the Blood Ravens as they take on a campaign to rid the planet of Tartarus of the war-loving, barbaric Orks.  What first starts out as a quest of extermination becomes a more complex conflict as more hostile factions enter the fray and a threat that could endanger the whole galaxy is discovered.  I will refrain from revealing much more about the story, but the campaign ends on a cliffhanger, all the more reason to buy DLC.  While the campaign is only 11 missions long and feels paced a little faster than it probably should be, the game attempts to compensate with each level taking anywhere between 1-2.5 hours, which probably explains why the story may have been rushed.  If you're a veteran of the RTS Genre, you may find the core game's campaign to be easy and manage to clear every level without failure.  Overall it's a story that justifies your actions and explores a small fragment of what it's like to be part of the Imperium of Man if nothing else, but that doesn't make it any less enjoyable.    3.5/5-Graphics:  The game was made in 2004, as a result the graphics you're going to see are going to be a little dated in contrast to the more modern landscapes and character designs known today, even on the higher settings.  As a result, the textures are going to be rather bland and lacking in detail in some places.  Obvious geometry for the most part isn't too noticeable, however animations are rather rigid and limited and you will probably start seeing the same actions get repeated, especially during the Campaign cutscenes.  Even with all the advancements in graphics throughout the years, Dawn of War ages surprisingly well.  You'll be able to notice the bloodshed, corpses, bullet holes and explosion residue left in craters as the battles rage, even if there are a few limitations.  The buildings are animated, so you'll know if your stuff is damaged, being built or whether something's happening, which is always useful in a fast-paced skirmish where information is vital.  Every faction has their own distinct style that's present in their architecture and Game UI, preventing the player from confusing one side for another. Overall, the game's graphics aren't the best I've seen, but it's pretty remarkable considering what was available at the time.   4/5-Gameplay:  Dawn of War is one of the simpler RTS games in terms of complexity.  The map is already drawn with every key point identified, however fog of war still exists, ensuring that  reconnaissance is still important.  There are only two resources to collect:  Requisition and Power, with the former being automatically generated (but sped up as you explore the map and claim more points) and the latter requiring the player to construct generators to collect.  Because of how requisition works, one never has to worry about the map being depleted of resources and being unable to build things, although it becomes much more difficult to construct anything when you have less buildings and points to generate resources.  There are also few kinds of units, which allow for simpler yet fewer strategies.  You will only encounter infantry, land vehicles and builders.  Fortunately the game not only classifies infantry as groups that can be reinforced and improved with your resources wherever they're located, it also avoids adding defenseless builders when you attempt to select your army.  There are four factions by default with more added in DLC, each promoting different strategies and play styles, but you're most likely going to be acquainted with the Jack of All Stat Space Marines from the campaign and the tutorial levels.  Speaking of the tutorial, every key aspect playing the game is covered in an easy to understand way that will allow newcomers to at least figure out what they're supposed to be doing.  One thing I will complain about is how limited the camera zooming is, as I tend to be unable to select all of my units that start occupying the entire screen, and at times your units may have difficulty simply going where you request them to, but not very often.  Before I forget, there is one aspect that separates Dawn of War from other Real-Time Strategy games:  Morale.  Yes, the often mistakenly overlooked aspect of war that must be maintained within your ranks.  Morale determines the survival of your units, and once its depleted they will start missing more often than a stormtrooper at point-blank range.  Naturally there are commander units that exist to boost morale and/or break enemy spirit that can be bound to infantry squads and can prove to be dangerous units with enough research and training.  Because of how morale works, it's never a good idea to send in a strike team that's outnumbered.   To summarize everything that was just typed, Dawn of War is one of the less complex RTS games you'll find, but that doesn't make it necessarily easy or boring.  4/5-Sound:  Everything sounds like what you'd expect it to, weapons, vehicles and all.  Each faction has their own idiosyncratic set of sound cues you'll associate them with.   While it is a minor annoyance to hear your units make an announcement every single time something involving them changes, anything said will always be relevant to the given situation with examples such as “Squad broken!” and “Under fire!”.  Everything your units say is not only standard, but reveals more of the personalities behind the unit type and the faction they hail from.  The background music is usually faint compared to the action, which is a good thing in this case because it doesn't distract from the more important aspect of this game:  Warfare.  While the background music fits the scenario, there isn't much else to say about this limited track.  Aside from the necessary announcements and some extra filler to avoid having the game sound too quiet, sound wasn't much of a focus on this game.  3.5/5-Replayability:  As games grow older and remain active through time, their replay value gradually diminishes and Dawn of War is no exception.  While the campaign may keep one occupied anywhere between a few days to a week at most, there is no real incentive to play this game for very long.  Skirmish mode may be fun for a few rounds to experiment with other factions and strategies, but aside from that there isn't much to say.  While there might have been an active multiplayer for the core game in the past, hardly anyone tends to roam the lobbies anymore.  Unless you know of other people who own the core game, you may end up never setting foot in the multiplayer community.  Fortunately there are three DLC expansion packs that can add more vitality for the game, with the majority of them being well-received as they incorporate new factions, campaigns and possibly fixes to whatever bugs exist and updates for the graphics.  With what little exists in the core game, DLC is practically a necessity, although it's important to keep in mind that Dawn of War has a sequel where the majority of users have most likely migrated to.  A little distressing, but what do you expect from an old game?  It's a miracle it's still even active.  3.5/5Summary/TL;DR:Dawn of War may not be the most complex Real-Time Strategy game out there, but that doesn't make it any less fun.  Overall score:  18.5/25  or 74%**Note:  This score is for the core game itself.  The expansion packs have not been evaluated by this user and may change the score.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
												This is a well-crafted RTS set in an interesting universe. It is not the usual "mass the biggest army and steamroll everything" RTS you normally get. As a novel idea, this strategy actually involves strategy! Who would have thought of such a thing. It's hardly perfect, and it is dated in a few ways, but it is well worth a playthrough.Pros:+Strategy. Seriously, you cannot simply throw your horde at the enemy and expect to win. It may not be the most in-depth strategy, but it does require some actual thought.+There's actually a story that is not overly contrived and generic. At the very least, you stay vested in what happens to your adorable little Blood Ravens.+This might be a con to some, but I like the fact there are only a handful of building, units, and research. I think it helps keep the action up when you can focus on actually conquering.+Warhammer...there seem to be roughly 40,000 of them.Cons:-Unit pathfinding and general movement is atrocious. Moving in groups is vital during combat, but you will often find yourself having to move squads one at a time in order to get them where you need them to be (and not stuck on each other).-There is only 1 faction to play as through the campaign.-Graphics are seriously date...but that is to be expected.-Maybe it's just me, but the cutscenes seem a bit long at times.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
												This is a well-crafted RTS set in an interesting universe. It is not the usual "mass the biggest army and steamroll everything" RTS you normally get. As a novel idea, this strategy actually involves strategy! Who would have thought of such a thing. It's hardly perfect, and it is dated in a few ways, but it is well worth a playthrough.Pros:+Strategy. Seriously, you cannot simply throw your horde at the enemy and expect to win. It may not be the most in-depth strategy, but it does require some actual thought.+There's actually a story that is not overly contrived and generic. At the very least, you stay vested in what happens to your adorable little Blood Ravens.+This might be a con to some, but I like the fact there are only a handful of building, units, and research. I think it helps keep the action up when you can focus on actually conquering.+Warhammer...there seem to be roughly 40,000 of them.Cons:-Unit pathfinding and general movement is atrocious. Moving in groups is vital during combat, but you will often find yourself having to move squads one at a time in order to get them where you need them to be (and not stuck on each other).-There is only 1 faction to play as through the campaign.-Graphics are seriously date...but that is to be expected.-Maybe it's just me, but the cutscenes seem a bit long at times.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
												Dawn of War is one of my favorite RTS games, even though I suck♥♥♥♥♥at them, Dawn of War is one I find myself picking up again and again to play. The game takes the setting in the Warhammer 40k universe and lets you control one of a few factions from the Warhammer lore to battle other players. The factions in this game are the Space Marines, Eldar, Orks, and Chaos Space Marines.The game, and the series, has many pros; the game has base building, units in squads, vehicles, and pretty decent destruction effects. The aingle player is decent I think and is a good few hours of gameplay and then the multiplayer is like a lot of RTS games however it has resource points you take and hold on the map to keep a steady flow of resources to your side to build buildings and troops. The game offers a variety of modes players can wage battle in such as take and hold (which is taking critical points and holding them to win), annihalation (which is just killing the other side), and capture the flag and so on. The only bad thing I think when it comes to this game is that it is an older game and a few computers have had issues running it but for the most part it seems to be able to run on the newer systems. If not then most fixes can be found online. In the end if you enjoy games like Company of Heroes, Starcraft, Warcraft, etc. then I would recommend this game. The gameplay is well done, pretty well balanced, and enjoyable to play with some friends or just to pass some times with. If you are a fan of the Warhammer 40k lore and setting than this game is great.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
												Good game but rather short on content.I know this is one of the more venerated RTS franchioses and mind you I liked it. The interface borrows from the Blizzard school of RTS as opposed to the Westwood School. You are given a fair amnount of info for each unit, it;s damage, it's strengths it's weakness, etc.However, it's rather scarce on content compared to many of it's peers. Little hint,. If you're going to have multiple factions in an RTS, it behooves you to at least due a story campaign for each of them. Heck even the ancient Dune 2 had a campaign for each house.Why is this an issue you may wonder. Well, while the marine campaign is indeed nice, I would have loved to play an ork campaign or a chaos camapin... you get what I'm saying? They've created a lovely universe with nicely done inhabitants but yet they confine you to just one.. I hear the expansions add more campaigns but those are extra which makes me wonder. ... Why? I mean I know Other games did this as well but again they gave you a solid offering for all factions before tacking on the extras.So while I can recommend, this game is rather low on my 'must buy' list because of that.Graphically it's pretty nice for it's time, quite nice, gameplay and strategy has a tendency to be a little linear. The squad idea is a nice aesthetic but really doesn't amount to much, gameplay wise. . FOr what I played during the free weekend fun but ... meh... not teh sort of RTS I would genuinely come back to again. It's just too generic in story and too linear in gameplay.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
												What can I say, accept that this game is awesome!  40k is best served as an RTS, even though I think they are heading towards a MOBA style after Dawn of War II gameplay style and Renicide.....at least as rumor has it :PJust going to jump right into it:PROSYou can make your owqn factionOk graphicsGreat MusicCan be used on lower-end computers (I have a higher end and a lower end)With friends to play with = Amazing! ...even vs AI compsPrice is great for all the fun possibleCONSCan't change Population max without a MODCommunity Online is quite dead (Also a few private with pass rq games)Units when under crtl+# do not act as intelligent as they could when staying together.MISCDoes not follow Warhammer Table-top 100% in damage distribution and armor, but close enoughAll-in-all a great all around game.  Even though it does not follow the rules of the real codex and mechanical understandings of weapons to armor, it does a great job all the same.  So if you love RTS this one is a bit different, but still an RTS to add to your collection.  If you love Warhammer Space Marine 40,000 then probably don't have to suggest this to you because you probably already own this... Basically a must buy to add to your Steam collection, even if just for solo skirmish mode.  You can also use this game to help you understand how the online 40k applies damage to certain armors and special abilities; which are somewhat different than table top, but seem to be reoccurring throughout 40k online games.Sirspoony's rating = 8.25/10    8.75 to 9/10 if community was not so dead

I'll pick you up. Looking sharp. Use the stairs. Your fatherpaid good money for those. Sorry. I'm excited. Here's the graduate.We're very proud of you, son. A perfect report card, all B's. Very proud. Ma! I got a thing going here. - You got lint on your fuzz.- Ow! That's me! - Wave to us! We'll be in row 118,000.- Bye! Barry, I told you,stop flying in the house! - Hey, Adam.- Hey, Barry. - Is that fuzz gel?- A little. Special day, graduation. Never thought I'd make it. Three days grade school,three days high school. Those were awkward. Three days college. I'm glad I tooka day and hitchhiked around the hive. You did come back different. - Hi, Barry.- Artie, growing a mustache? Looks good. - Hear about Frankie?- Yeah. - You going to the funeral?- No, I'm not going. Everybody knows,sting someone, you die. Don't waste it on a squirrel.Such a hothead. I guess he could havejust gotten out of the way. I love this incorporatingan amusement park into our day. That's why we don't need vacations. Boy, quite a bit of pomp...under the circumstances. - Well, Adam, today we are men.- We are! - Bee-men.- Amen! Hallelujah! Students, faculty, distinguished bees, please welcome Dean Buzzwell. Welcome, New Hive Oitygraduating class of... ...9:15. That concludes our ceremonies. And begins your careerat Honex Industries! Will we pick ourjob today? I heard it's just orientation. Heads up! Here we go. Keep your hands and antennasinside the tram at all times. - Wonder what it'll be like?- A little scary. Welcome to Honex,a division of Honesco and a part of the Hexagon Group. This is it! Wow. Wow. We know that you, as a bee,have worked your whole life to get to the point where youcan work for your whole life. Honey begins when our valiant PollenJocks bring the nectar to the hive. Our top-secret formula is automatically color-corrected,scent-adjusted and bubble-contoured into this soothing sweet syrup with its distinctivegolden glow you know as... Honey! - That girl was hot.- She's my cousin! - She is?- Yes, we're all cousins. - Right. You're right.- At Honex, we constantly strive to improve every aspectof bee existence. These bees are stress-testinga new helmet technology. - What do you think he makes?- Not enough. Here we have our latest advancement,the Krelman. - What does that do?- Oatches that little strand of honey that hangs after you pour it.Saves us millions. Oan anyone work on the Krelman? Of course. Most bee jobs aresmall ones. But bees know that every small job,if it's done well, means a lot. But choose carefully because you'll stay in the jobyou pick for the rest of your life. The same job the rest of your life?I didn't know that. What's the difference? You'll be happy to know that bees,as a species, haven't had one day off in 27 million years. So you'll just work us to death? We'll sure try. Wow! That blew my mind! "What's the difference?"How can you say that? One job forever?That's an insane choice to have to make. I'm relieved. Now we only haveto make one decision in life. But, Adam, how could theynever have told us that? Why would you question anything?We're bees. We're the most perfectlyfunctioning society on Earth. You ever think maybe thingswork a little too well here? Like what? Give me one example. I don't know. But you knowwhat I'm talking about. Please clear the gate.Royal Nectar Force on approach. Wait a second. Oheck it out. - Hey, those are Pollen Jocks!- Wow. I've never seen them this close. They know what it's likeoutside the hive. Yeah, but some don't come back. - Hey, Jocks!- Hi, Jocks! You guys did great! You're monsters!You're sky freaks! I love it! I love it! - I wonder where they were.- I don't know. Their day's not planned. Outside the hive, flying who knowswhere, doing who knows what. You can'tjust decide to be a PollenJock. You have to be bred for that. Right. Look. That's more pollenthan you and I will see in a lifetime. It's just a status symbol.Bees make too much of it. Perhaps. Unless you're wearing itand the ladies see you wearing it. Those ladies?Aren't they our cousins too? Distant. Distant. Look at these two. - Oouple of Hive Harrys.- Let's have fun with them. It must be dangerousbeing a Pollen Jock. Yeah. Once a bear pinned meagainst a mushroom! He had a paw on my throat,and with the other, he was slapping me! - Oh, my!- I never thought I'd knock him out. What were you doing during this? Trying to alert the authorities. I can autograph that. A little gusty out there today,wasn't it, comrades? Yeah. Gusty. We're hitting a sunflower patchsix miles from here tomorrow. - Six miles, huh?- Barry! A puddle jump for us,but maybe you're not up for it. - Maybe I am.- You are not! We're going 0900 at J-Gate. What do you think, buzzy-boy?Are you bee enough? I might be. It all dependson what 0900 means. Hey, Honex! Dad, you surprised me. You decide what you're interested in? - Well, there's a lot of choices.- But you only get one. Do you ever get boreddoing the same job every day? Son, let me tell you about stirring. You grab that stick, and you justmove it around, and you stir it around. You get yourself into a rhythm.It's a beautiful thing. You know, Dad,the more I think about it, maybe the honey fieldjust isn't right for me. You were thinking of what,making balloon animals? That's a bad jobfor a guy with a stinger. Janet, your son's not surehe wants to go into honey! - Barry, you are so funny sometimes.- I'm not trying to be funny. You're not funny! You're goinginto honey. Our son, the stirrer! - You're gonna be a stirrer?- No one's listening to me! Wait till you see the sticks I have. I could say anything right now.I'm gonna get an ant tattoo! Let's open some honey and celebrate! Maybe I'll pierce my thorax.Shave my antennae. Shack up with a grasshopper. Geta gold tooth and call everybody "dawg"! I'm so proud. - We're starting work today!- Today's the day. Oome on! All the good jobswill be gone. Yeah, right. Pollen counting, stunt bee, pouring,stirrer, front desk, hair removal... - Is it still available?- Hang on. Two left! One of them's yours! Oongratulations!Step to the side. - What'd you get?- Picking crud out. Stellar! Wow! Oouple of newbies? Yes, sir! Our first day! We are ready! Make your choice. - You want to go first?

content:
Posted: February 19, 2016
												You know how some RTS games age really well? Dune 2, all the Warcraft games, etc? Well, this is not one of them. The game models don't have a lot of polys, and textures don't have a lot of pixels in them, sure, but this is not the problem. They also don't have any style or imagination. Gameplay is straightforward and boring, too: the same as in any other right-clicking RTS game you played before. And the story... WH40k universe offers a lot of real, gritty gothic stories of unimaginable horrors and deep space nightmares. This is definetly not one of them though.If you think that this game has any value other than nostalgic, think again. And don't buy it.

number of helpful: 5 of 21 people (24%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2015
												At this point, I could honestly only suggest this game to hardcore RTS fans, specifically those who are into WarCraft 3 but could expand into some new lore and mechanics. It's just aged a great deal. It looks and feels bad. The soundtrack seems on par with the sequels though, and there seems to be plenty of story in the campaign, and a neat territorial conquest theme to the campaign that the DoW2 series did not have.Now, I'm typically not a fan of true RTS games, which might be why I feel like Dawn of War 2 was a vastly superior set of games in ALL ways, but I can understand that the first Dawn of War series of content here can hold some people's attention. They're definitely more focused on more multitasking and bigger squadrons. That kind of stuff honestly just hurts my brain. I much prefer DoW2's 4-Hero Unit campaign structure, and it's Last Stand mode (though now largely unplayed).As far as multiplayer goes, I cannot comment, as I know my role there. I am no use to any team. That's probably where this first series shines, from what I hear.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												A good old-fashioned RTS set in the Warhammer 40k universe. Runs smoothly, easy to learn but hard to master, looks pretty good for an older game, engaging story mode and addicting co-op/ai mode. I wish more people were on the online multiplayer, but I'm happy popping on to play an hour-long game against a bunch of bots. My friend and I once had a 6-hour long game with us on a team against multiple teams of hard bots. Recommend for anybody who likes RTS games, but not for the whiney newer generation of gamers who think anything without triple-a cutting edge graphics is bad.

												If there was a neutral vote id put thatbut it does tip towards the no. One reason being when i first saw this i was like HOLY♥♥♥♥♥♥ITS A WARHAMMER VID GAME OFC ITS GOIN TO BE GREAT!!!Then i started to play and dont get me wrong very nice for its time but it lacks the warhammer feel.... the feeling of controlling thousands of troops at once, the feeling of aww man 50 of my guys died but thats alright i got 500 more to throw into the fray that kinda feel if u ever look at the artwork for battles in the codexes and books it depicts humongous batttles where thousans (im sorry i ment MILLIONS) of troops are thrown at eachother while this when i was getting to the mid campaign where the orcs supposedly are infesting the cities flooding in in the thousands where as the actual level i only got to kill 100-150 orcs max eachtime this is a great game dont get me wrong but it lacks the mass troops and the base building is just horrible. no room to build no freedom as to where i want my barracks to be or my turret to be dead smack in the middle of me base incase of sky boyz and stuff I know warhammer battlemarch came out way WAY later then this but if they were goin to setup a campaign why not like that where you get 20 squads to work with in the beginning (maybe alittle more since ya kno BIG BATTLES NED MUST HAZ) then have a battle deployment i mean they couldve done so much more with this but they chose not to and went with base building i mean come on where in the history of the tabletop game did base building matter you simply had a equal force as your enemy and the roll of the dice along with your strategy to win you the day not resources or higher tech level it simply didnt matter so why should it have mattered now.And dawn of war 2 was a complete waste of the title its simply 4 squads every level where as they took out the need for a base (which was nice) but took away EVEN MORE troops so it felt so empty like there was this perfectly good battle field with no able bodies to fill it inch by inch.Now if your a warhammer fan and have played the tabletop games and other things warhammer i suggest this to you but if your the lore fan who thought of warhammer 40k as a age of mass DA MEN EVERYWHERE then dont get this its a waste they couldve done so much more but they chose to go down a route that wasnt ever their stle when deving thids game

content:
Posted: October 2, 2016
												It's very old, and it shows horribly in both graphics and gameplay.First annoyance: Whenever you boot it up it goes to the Steam overlay, prompting you to CREATE YOUR RELIC ACCOUNT. Yeah, nope, attrocious. Give it a rest already.While the campaign is entertaining in a B-movie way and the small animations of your Terminators crushing enemies are both brutal and fun to watch, your troops start messing up as soon as you have more than 10 of them; clustering together in tight spots, stopping on their way to attack-move somewhere so you need to issue another order to get them going, and having the map central on units immediately when selecting them forcing you to go back to where the action is/was to order them where to attack (as opposed to Star Craft gameplay where centralizing on units only occurs if you double click the shortcut for the unit).Case in point: Your troops captures a relic point. You then select a servant to build a listening post, however the camera goes to that unit instead of just selecting it while still being over the listening point area you just captured, making you have to click on the map where that point was and then clicking on the place you want to build again - every damn time you want to build something. It's really jarring and halts your progression and flow in a very tedious, frustrating manner.I'm sure this was decent for its time, but games have moved on since then and it's just too old and finicky to compete. Adding to that, it has no resolutions for 1920x1080 and the camera, even when zoomed all the way out, is way to close to your troops and ground to get what you'd consider a normal overview in RTS games.Only get it in a bundle as I did, or stay away, even on a sale.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												The game itself is a fun RTS, but the issues hold it back for me. I've tried it on multiple computers since I bought it a few years ago, and I can't get more than halfway through a mission without it crashing on me. A huge disappointment, since the little bit of time I've managed to play it was good. It doesn't have widescreen support built in (there's a fan-made patch to add it, but it's still not perfect), but I honestly enjoyed it enough (again, while it worked) not to mind black borders on the sides of my screen.Since so many other people have had it run fine for them, it's almost definitely something about the computers I've tried playing it on. Don't spend a cent on it unless you know for certain it works on your computer (try the demo first!).I only have half an hour listed because I only added it to Steam hoping they had fixed the issues in the newest patches. It's still crashing as often as it did when I installed it from my boxed copy.

number of helpful: 10 of 56 people (18%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2013
												I know shouldn't let the Campaign overly influence my opinion on this game, but man I found this boring. It hasn't aged very well at all. I can forgive the poor draw distance, and the chunky graphics, as technology moves on long after games have been made.Yet... the story was pretty boring and by the book, which is a shame when you consider the huge amount of lore you can draw from the Warhammer Universe. Like other RTS before and after it, Dawn of War suffers from the ease in which you can build up a super army and just blitz your way through the map. There are some nice animations and kill sequences within the game, which is a nice little touch.I'll give this game another go somewhere down the line and play Skirmmish/Multiplayer against other people, which I think will be a fairer reflection on what it has to offer.I do like the idea of the Army Painter tool to create unique paint designs.

number of helpful: 3 of 38 people (8%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 6, 2014
												While I did play this game from start to finish, I would not recrommend it when compared to much better games of the same genre. Had I bought this game when it first came out as opposed to a steam sale several years after it's release I would probably say this game is great. Starcraft is a much better game in comparison. I am mostly writing this review to say not to buy Warhammer 40,000 because it is like any other strategy game on the market. I think consumers would be happier buying Warhammer 40,000 (2) as the gameplay is less repetative and more exciting sicne your squad mates use cover and throw grenades to take over vital positions (kind of like Company of Heroes mixed with Starcraft). I would have been fine skipping on the first 3 Warhammer 40,000 games and just owning Retribution 2 with all of its expansions.  I own all the Warhammer 40,000 Franchise games and that is my honest opinion.

Posted: January 22, 2014
												Arnold Ray "Bake" McBride (born February 3, 1949 in Fulton, Missouri), also nicknamed "Shake n' Bake" and "The Callaway Kid", is a former Major League Baseball outfielder, known primarily as a member of the Philadelphia Phillies' teams of the late 1970s and early 1980s. Selected in the 37th round in 1970 as the 811th player,[1] he made his major league debut for the St. Louis Cardinals in 1974, finishing the season with 173 base hits, 30 stolen bases, and a .309 batting average, and was named the National League's Rookie of the Year, the first Cardinal to earn the award since Bill Virdon in 1955. On June 15, 1977, McBride was traded, with Steve Waterbury, by the St. Louis Cardinals to the Phillies for Tom Underwood, Dane Iorg, and Rick Bosetti.On February 16, 1982, McBride was traded to the Cleveland Indians for Sid Monge. On November 7, 1983, he was granted free agency, but chose to retire from baseball.

Posted: February 27
												Yep. It's old, but it's one of the most defining RTS during its time.Quick recommendation: If you want the 100% Dawn of War 1 experience, get Dawn of War: Soulstorm + Ultimate Apocalypse mod, instead. But if you want to really introduce yourself slowly to the Warhammer 40000 universe without clotting your head with too many stuff at once, play this one first.I used to own all of the DoW games once, pirated. Being used to Warcraft and Starcraft as pioneer RTSes, I thought, ya why not. Another space-sci-fi RTS. Recently I bought all DoW titles on Steam, just to remind and appreciate how Dawn of War introduces me to an uber-awesome sci-fi universe which is WARHAMMER 40000.This game opened doors for me. It introduces me to the dark, grim and hopeless Warhammer 40000 franchise. From there I get to know that GW miniatures are a thing, and am hooked to collecting and painting the minis now. And Warcraft and Starcraft actually are inspired by the Warhammer and Warhammer 40000 franchises, respectively.Back to the game, this is one of those innovative RTSes where you can control an entire 'unit' (or squad) of up to 9-10 soldiers instead of training them one-by-one a la War/Starcraft. This allows bigger battles with more units on screen. Other innovative things are all units can engage in either ranged or melee combat. Why melee in a sci-fi universe, you ask? Well melee is a big feature in the Warhammer 40000 universe, where combats tend to get up close and personal.So within those melee combat, they will sometimes have 'sync kills' where some of your/enemy's troops will execute a brutal melee kill animation that's really fun to watch. Other innovative things in this RTS is certain bigger units like walkers and monsters will be able to mow down and toss smaller troops around, and this really brings the battlefield alive.Am really excited Dawn of War III, the third installment of this franchise that is coming soon. And if you really are interested in delving into the universe without purchasing the overpriced models, codexes and books, this game is a must play to get you the general feeling and atmosphere of the Warhammer 40000 universe/franchise. It is a very good entry point to the overly complex universe.

Posted: March 7
												Altough I do not play the table top game, but i find that this game is the best way of starting to get into the MASSIVE world of Warhammer, as it goes without saying that it is a considerable amount cheaper and more enclusive. A squad of Night Lord chaos Space Marines at full strenght and an Aspiring Champion cost about 565 points in game, which are free. The same squad would cost about £50 (I've looked at a start up pack which is around 15 figures) for much the same. That unit then takes hours to make and paint, and then will end up on a shelf until you buy about 3 more units, a Land Speeder and a Librarian, at which point you have to drive to the shop (Because those units wont fit on a bike) and play some annoying nerd who keeps telling you your doing it wrong, or that you don't know enough about Konrad Curze's former life in a hive city and his subsiquent fall to the forces of chaos to play as the Night Lords. On the other hand, in game you can play agaisnt a well balanced A.I of adiquate difficulty which CANT TALK, and along side countless other sqauds and even other leigons in 2v2v2v2 skirmish matches of annihaliton or economic based battles in a bid to control the battlefield. You do the math. £6.99 or £609.99. I've even bought the £99.99 expansion package. Still worth it.

Posted: March 30, 2014
												This is the game that really got me back into RTS after years of docile activity. It has laughable graphics, but the story and characters just feel and look really cool. The building system is very much like Company of Heroes or Starcraft, but seem to be simplified in a way that players can pick it up easy and still feel like they're getting a challenge without the frustrating factor of "how do i do ____." In some ways, I view this game as superior to Dawn of War 2, but I'd still recommend buying both. Another important thing to note is that you don't have to know anything about the Warhammer series to enjoy this game. I came in knowing little more than it was about space marines or something. The story gives a good backstory and explanation for the universe, inviting players from all background rather than shunning those who do not follow the series. I don't really have a complaint except that maybe an updated HD version should be made (Though I don't really care much since, as old as it looked, I still liked how it did present itself).Gameplay: 10/10Story: 9/10Graphics: 7/10Characters: 9/10Replayability: 10/10

Posted: April 5, 2014
												This was the game that got me into the Warhammer 40k Universe. The gameplay is fantastic for an RTS, you have only two types of resources, requisition and power so you have to go out and capture requisition points and defend them to maintain a source of requisition, this keeps you in constant conflict with the other factions as they need it as much as you.This kind of "Need for war", makes the game so action packed for a strategy game. There are only 4 factions, and each of them with different units and abilities. The campaign was great, both in story and battles, but it's a shame that they only made a campaign for the Space Marines.Overall, this is a great example of a Real Time Strategy game, one with an extensive lore behind it and innovative gameplay.

Posted: February 17, 2012
												Ever wonder where Blizzard got most of their ideas for the Warcraft and Starcraft games? Look no further than Warhammer. This long-running series started out in the '80s as a tabletop strategy game, and transitioned to computer games not long after. The Dawn of War series takes place in the Warhammer 40,000 universe, and will have a very familiar feel to anyone who has played Blizzard's popular RTS games. No doubt you're already familiar with Space Marines and Orks. You'll find plenty of them here. Starcraft's Protoss and Zerg drew their inspiration from Warhammer's Eldar and Tyranid races, respectively. You'll also find several other factions unique to Warhammer, including the corrupt Chaos Marines, the undead robotic Necron, and the alien Tau. Even though the Dawn of War series was originally released in 2004, it still stands the test of time, and the many expansion packs keep things fresh and interesting. If you're a fan of any sci-fi RTS games, you'll love Dawn of War.

Posted: December 29, 2012
												One of my favourite strategy games of all-time, Dawn of War is a real-time strategy game set in the futuristic Warhammer 40000 universe.Like most strategy games, you have a base building. You build more buildings which give you access to units and abilities. You can then uprgrade units and building to improve your army. To build buildings or units you need resources which can be acquired by capturing points and buildng power stations. Buildings, units, abilities and playstyles change according to the race that you choose. In the original Dawn of War, you have access to 4 races: Space Marines, Chaos, Orcs and Eldar. In the single player campaign mode, you play as the Space Marines in a story driven campaign. The storyline is interesting enough to keep you engaged and maps are varied enough to stay interesting for whatever difficulty level you have selected.There are also single player scenarios, where you pick and any army and map and then play. Also there is online multiplayer to play with human opponents. Maps can hold between 2 and 8 players who can be divided into teams if desired.There is also a customiser where you can choose a race and customise the look of your units and buildings to create a unique looking army for yourself.There are also 3 expansions which further build on this: Winter Assault, Dark Crusade and Soulstorm.Winter Assault features new maps, storyline and the addition of the Imperial Guard race. The storyline features the option to play through it as Good (Imperial Guard and Eldar) or Evil (Chaos and Orks) with an ending that changes depending on who you pick to play the final mission with.Dark Crusade again features completely new maps, storyline, addition of the Tau race and the Necron race as well as new units for existing races. The single player game is changed slightly as you now have an overworld view of the planet that all these races are fighting on. You choose which areas you wish to battle in first. The more areas you acquire, the more resources that are open to you. You can also acquire honor guard units (rare powerful hero units) as well as equipment to give to your race's leader, which enhances their stats and abilities. This gives the game a pseudo-RPG element. You eliminate other races by invading their home region and taking it, but they can do the same to do.Again, the storyline is engaging enough, but not as immersive or as intense as in the previous games.Soulstorm once again builds further on what has come before by featuring more completely new maps, storyline, addition of the Sisters of Battle race and the Dark Eldar race, as well as even more units for existing races. The single layer features an overworld view of several planets and maintains the pseudo-RPG elements of Dark Crusade. Overall, this is a great strategy series to get is you are a fan of the genre or of Warhammer 40000 in general.

Posted: July 19, 2014
												This game takes what you love about the tabletop (action, strategy, troop management/movement, a killing Orks) and leaves what you don't (spending money). If you are a 40k fan, and also a gamer, there's no reason not to have this game.This is your typical RTS, that utilizes buildings that make infantry, other buildings that make vehicles, and gathering resources (although the resource gathering is much more simplified than in Age of Empires, or even Command and Conquer). Fairly intuitive, this game lets you hop right into the action. You can even "paint" your army and save a custom scheme in case you don't want to ruin the defaults for the different races.This game isn't as in depth as the tabletop as far as the disparity of units. For example, in this game, the Blood Angels have the exact infantry and vehicle choices as the ultramarines. And air vehicles are missing entirely. But still, well done, and true to the source material.I not only recommend this game, but I also bought it and gifted it to a friend so he could play with me. (In multiplayer mode. The campaign is completely single player.)

Posted: January 11, 2013
												I've ONLY played the single-player campaign and it was very enjoyable. The campaign has a very good story that borrows a lot from the actual WH franchise, so those familiar with the Space Marines should have a lot to look forward too. The plot's fleshed out by interesting and some what lengthy cutscenes before and after each mission. The voice actors in the game are very over the top and sometimes cheesy, but they manage to fit each character well and the voice acting actually comes away as a very bright spot in the game for me.Game-play wise there isn't a whole lot of 'new' here compared to other RTS games, but what is included is polished. For its release date I consider the game to be very technically capable with things like decent character animations and solid over-all performance. Fans of RTS games or the Warhammer franchise should definitely give this one a shot.

Posted: February 23, 2016
												This is the first RTS I have played in several years, and the first Warhammer game I have ever played. After finishing the campaign in 14 hours and playing a bit of team based multiplayer with a few of my friends I have come to the conclusion that this game is at least a 9/10 The Warhammer 40k world is a richly expansive universe of the same quality as other such giants in the industry such as Starcraft and Warcraft. All characters are loveable, interesting, and at least memorable. Running into battle with a group of fully upgraded space marines against an opposing force is uplifting as it is intense and exciting. I tend to prefer RPG's and tactical shooters, but Dawn of War is a game that everyone should play at least once. As I can honestly say that after finishing the campaign mode I am now obsessed with the universe and have been doing everything in my power to learn more about it. Do yourself a favor and purchase this gorgeous gem of a game.

Posted: January 28
												Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War is in my opinion the best RTS game of all time, and it is just fantastic.Story:- I don't know that much of the Warhammer lore, but as far as I know, it follows it really well. If it doesn't, it still delivers a good and satisfying story!Gameplay:- The gameplay is where this game shines, with different races to play as on over 30 maps, this game never gets old. All races have the same basics, but late game it changes. I won't spoil anything of it, because I think everyone who is a fan of the genre or a fan of the Warhammer universe should play this. There are, as said above, over 30 maps to play on, and all of them are different in some way. Every map is challenging to master, and it adds brilliantly to the replay value and enjoyment.Graphics:- Graphics don't add anything to the overall enjoyment of the game in my opinion, and it doesn't do that here either. The graphics were great for their time, and though the textures definitely look dated, they do hold up over 12 years after its official release.Verdict:Dawn of War is the definitive RTS experience, and it is definitely worth the money, though if you're after graphics, you should probably go for Sins Of The Solar Empire. The game gets a 8/10 from me.- Denolact

												Note to myself : rewrite this feedback later, it's unreadable. If you like RTS where your weakest unit can last longer than 1 second and tough units are mean to be tough (they'll last longer than 5 seconds even when things are really intenses, and will win a 1v20 against weak units), then this game is for you. Quite easy to start with (Game Tutorial for beginner), Dawn of War 1 is a classical "build your base, create your army and crush your opponents" game, where you can get both a high amount of units and "Nokia" units (yeah, you won't be able to take them down in less than 10 seconds unless you have enough dakka). The skirmish setting gives you the opportunity to choose between different victory condition (ex : annihilate the enemy, kill the enemy's leader, get enough ressources, ...). If you already played to a Blizzard RTS (Warcraft 3 or Starcraft), you'll discover a new way to get ressources : forget everything about harvesting ressources. Ressources increase automatically : build a Generator, and you'll get Energy over time (+10/sec for each generator, but you'll get 1 energy each 0.1 second). The more you build generator, the faster you'll get Energy (and they'll continue giving ressources, until you or your enemy destroy them). Thus you don't have to worry about "units harvesting ressources" or "exhausting all the map ressources" : just focus on the battle and use your ressources wisely. This game also has memorable ambient music (look out for «Blood Ravens Approach») and nice sync kills too, especially when a heavy unit "crushes" smaller units.Edit : Forgot to mention it, but effectiveness and ineffectiveness (between units) are really applied in this game (a sniper can easily one hit kill an infantry or deal 300 damages to a heavy infantry, but try it out on a building and you'll do less than 20 damages).

Posted: July 13, 2015
												Not much to say here; I've played RTS games my whole life, since I was a kid, and this is one of the best around. Streamlined resource managment that ties well into gameplay, and a central mechanic that encourages tactics and strategy. Plus, it's Warhammer 40,000. I knew nothing about the universe or table-top game going into this and its because of this game that I've fully embraced the "grim darkness of the far future," in all its glory. Do yourself a favor, buy this game, play it, and bring honor to your troops and the Emperor!

Posted: July 10, 2015
												Note: This game and it's numerous expansions track playtime differently, I have played more than this it is just divided amongst all the expansions which makes playtime harder to truly calculate. Dawn Of War is one of the best RTS games I've ever seen and is definitely worth the purchase and all of it's dlcs, at the time of writing they were all on sale for a combined price lower than 10 dollars, that is an absolute steal. In short, Dawn Of War is an RTS that contains:- 9 Incredibly unique factions ranging from the undead/robotic necron, who do not require requisitions but need to build massive amounts of power to sustain themselves to the legendary Warhammer Space Marines, the super soldiers who define the series with their powerful leadership units and decent unit composition making impossible fights slightly more possible (Though the expansions are needed for 5 of them, by default you get Orks, Chaos Marines, Space Marines, and Eldar though they are pretty unique and can in themselves offer hundreds of hours of gameplay).-Interesting game modes such as the standard destroy the enemy's base ranging to hold various points for a set amount of time or even just slay the enemy commander before yours falls. Plus, you can set more than one victory parameter for maximum gameplay and strategic influence. -Expansions that change the singleplayer experience (Soulstorm and Dark Crusade) to a map takeover in which all of the game's factions wage war and fight numerous matches attacking and defending territory with troops they earned throughout the campaign and even their fation specific commander his/herself.In the end, it is an amazing game well worth your time, though I do suggest getting the expansions as they make the already great game even better.

Posted: May 4, 2015
												An absolutely brilliant adaption of the Warhammer 40,000 tabletop game to real-time strategy. Relic hits it out of the park in nailing the look and feel of Warhammer 40K, while providing for fluid real-time gameplay - including base building. There is suprising depth to the strategic elements of the game, and the sides are well balanced despite being very distinct. Most highly recommended. Dark Crusade and Soulstorm add even more fun and depth to the mix.

Posted: April 25, 2015
												To start: I used to add a much longer header to these reviews, but since it often made the reviews too long to submit, I've opted to leave it on my Backloggery.Gameplay: One thing that's very difficult not to do when talking about any base-building RTS, let alone a military Sci-Fi RTS, is to not compare it to Starcraft, especially considering the influence that the Warhammer 40k world present in Starcraft. After all, there's a race of humans kinda like the Terrans, there's an alien race like the Protoss, and while not present in this game, there is a race similar to the Zerg. Also much like Starcraft, the gameplay is centered around building bases.The differences come in, as you might expect, with the gameplay. While this is something of a personal taste, I really do quite like how resources are handled in this game. Your two basic resources are Requisition (kinda like Minerals) and Power (kinda like Vespene). You gain requisition from controlling Strategic Points on the map. It is also from these Strategic Points that you build your base, from which you can build in a radius that expands up to a certain point. Unlike Starcraft, you gain resources at a set rate per minute, which is slow enough to require you to think about what you wanna build, as opposed to spamming harvesters all day. Power is gained from building generators, and much like Requisition, is gained at a set rate per minute. There are also Slag Deposits on some maps, which you can capture and build a special generator on, allowing a bit more strategy with your expansion.Units are produced in squads, and vehicles have their own unit cap outside of the squad unit cap. With some research, you can increase your squad cap to 20, and your vehicle cap to 10. While this doesn't sound like much, keep in mind that each squad can have up to ten people in it, reaching Starcraft's famous 200 unit limit very easily, and surpassing it with vehicle count. I do wish that your construction units didn't count as one squad, which can be especially obnoxious as there is no way of recalling your construction units other than sending them out to maybe punch the enemy's base or something.While the game doesn't necessarily have as many units as Starcraft, the matter of unit composition is largely handled by equipment. Your basic squad can be outfitted with four different special weapons, of which each squad can have up to four specially equipped members. Another aspect to this game is its Morale system, in which you can use particularly gruesome attacks to break apart squads, leaving them easy for the pickings as well as discouraging some easy rushes from time to time. The single player campaign is somewhat disappointing, as it only features the Space Marines. I'll talk more about the story later, but for now know that there aren't Eldar, Ork or Chaos Marine campaigns (Eldar being the kinda-Protoss race and Necron being the unlisted kinda-Zerg race). There are apparently campaigns in the expansions, but since I haven't played them yet, I can't speak for them.Now, we come to the important question: how fun is the game? This was my first "legit" introduction to the Real-Time Strategy genre, and I gotta say; I picked a damn good game to start out with. The gameplay is very streamlined, there's usually a great bit of action going on at any one time, and the mechanics are simple enough on the surface while still having a good bit of depth to it for people to play for quite some time. If you're looking for an RTS to get someone's feet wet with, I can very easily recommend this one over Starcraft (although Starcraft may take a bit of weening into) for first timers to the genre. Simple on the surface, deep underneath, very streamlined and just overall a hell of a lot of fun to play. 9/10.Story: Since the completion of this game, I've gone on and read some more of the Warhammer 40k lore, and I've gotta be honest; the campaign doesn't do the series justice. The content is kinda neat, and the Orks are still fun to watch bumble about, but for the Space Marines, this game doesn't do very good in showcasing just how grand their empire is. It feels kinda... fanfic-y, in a not so great way. They try to do some intrigue, but it just doesn't work, and the cliffhanger at the end is, to be quite frank, inexcusable. While the dialogue and writing in-game is good, the actual story itself just isn't good. At all. Disappointing. 6/10.Graphics: Unfortunately, to get this game to run at 1080p I had to download some modded files, which may trigger anti-cheat protection if you happen to play multiplayer. Also, running these files breaks the HUD for the Space Marines (although strangely not for any of the other races). It's frustrating, and I really would expect Sega to get around to making 1080p available in-game without any modding required. Despite this, the game looks pretty good for a 2004 game. Unit design is pretty neat, most of the areas that you visit throughout the campaign look really cool, and of course, seeing an Ork mech tear a Space Marine in half is just plain awesome. I never suffered any frame drops, which is always nice for an older game, as older games around this generation like to depend entirely on your integrated graphics chip if you happen to have one, leaving your GPU idling uselessly. 4.5 for not having 1080p available by default, but the half point comes in because a mod is very easy to download and install.Sound: The voice acting during the cutscenes isn't bad, but it's not exactly award winning work either. Voice acting in battle is pretty good, though, especially for the Orks (I may also have a bit of an Ork bias). The music is pretty excellent as well, and is definitely memorable. It's pretty much entirely orchestral, but it's very "heavy," with loads of brass and percussion; just the way I like my orchestras. Apart from that, there's not much else to talk about here. Good stuff. 4/5.Overall scores are: 9/6/4.5/4; cumulative score of 7.8/10. Again, the biggest problem with the game is the campaign being kinda not good, but at least skirmishing is a lot of fun. Still though, the campaign is disappointing, especially considering that Relic made Homeworld.

Posted: June 24, 2015
												This is the game that started it all for me. This is the game that put me on the path to become a Warhammer 40,000 fanboy (PC and literature, not tabletop). The setting is the distopian Warhammer 40,000 universe where a planet is beset by Orks (with a "k") and the Space Marines are sent to liberate the planet. Confusion and twists, Eldar and Chaos, follows.This game was best known as introducing the new squad based fighting units. Instead of creating your army one unit at a time, you can now create an entire squad of a specific unit and have it fight as a whole. It moved the focus from resource gathering to strategic point captures, freeing up your focus from managing gatheres to managing your army.The single player campaign, unfortunately, only follows the Space Marine storyline, so it seems quite short. However, you can still play with the other races in either multiplayer or skirmishes.

Posted: August 20, 2015
												I have never really bothered to play a Warhammer game, or even the board game. But after playing Dawn of War I can safely say that Warhammer has been cemented in my memory as an excellent rts with excellent lore behind it.You begin as a commander of the forces of the Imperium of Man finds himself outnumbered by orks, a race of green humanoids hell-bent on conquering everything. The storyline, although short, is one of the most interesting I've seen in an RTS, and it is easy to follow, even if you know nothing about the Warhammer lore. It evolves into a decent ending, with elements for a sequel clearly present.This game, as an RTS, is brilliantly executed. Rather than buying a single unit, you buy a squad of units, each with its own health bar, which you can reinforce, upgrade weapons, and beef up to take on the challenges that lie ahead. This applies only to infantry, however, as vehicles are a single unit, with their own strengths and weaknesses. The variety of tools available to you ensures that no matter the task, You will have everything needed at your disposal. In addition, workers do not gather resources, rather capturing strategic points generates them, which takes an element of micomanagement away from the game, making it more acessible. Your squads tend to have good lasting power, and remain useful even very late into the game. Just as well, as they tend to be pretty expensive. Also, they have a morale system; when things are going good, morale stays high and your units fight normally. Face them against a flamethrower or other psycologically devastating weapon, and the squad will break, severely reducing its effectiveness. this is a great feature, and as far as I can tell one unique to the warhammer franchise.All in all, I strongly recommend this game. The campagn is rather short, however you'll find yourself having had too much fun to really care, and the multiplayer is an excellent addition.

												Be careful! Warhammer 40k Dawn of War - Game of the Year Edition doesn't include Winter Assault and any other expansions. GotY edition is kinda misleading here, since in most games it means that there is every DLC/expansion/add-on etc. included.Warhammer 40.000: Dawn of War was one of first games I owned on Steam. I remember when I bought it shortly after release (box edition) and for some reason I thought it would be cool to start somehow with Steam. And here I got it. Didn't spend then much time playing (just a few mission and skirmish) and I moved along to other games. Few days ago I wanted to recall how amazing first Dawn of War game is. Even after almost 10 years this strategy game looks amazing. It didn't get old at all. The main story maybe isn't the longer in strategy games (just 11 missions) but the harder difficulty level you play on, the more fun it is. There are much more skirmish maps, where you can play with much more players/ai and have even more fun. Not just as Space Marines, but also as Orks or Chaos Space Marines. If skirmish and story aren't enough for you, there is also multiplayer! It still have active community, so if you want a great strategy game for online purpose, I think Warhammer 40k Dawn of War is good choice too. Hardcore fans of Warhammer will probably happy with one more think - army painter.In my opinion, Warhammer 40.000: Dawn of War is one of these games that should be played by every gamer. And if you call yourself a fan of strategy games then you must play it.

Posted: August 13, 2015
												A decent tabletop to video game conversion. Age of Empires II attempted to use in-game dialogue to simulate real time discussions and events between people in RTS games, but Dawn of War manages to make it even more believeable with the closer camera and the more dynamic movements of the models. The story is riveting, suspensful and startling towards the end. Anyone who enjoys a futuristic crusade and a struggle between good and evil should certainly follow this chronicle. The add-on system of weapons, unit commanders and special attacks enhance the game play in a variety of ways. A menagerie of units is available to not only the Imperium, but the Orks and the Forces of Choas. The map design is very good and the structures are both impressive and fearsome sights. The voice over work is very theatrical and the cut scenes strongly resemble stage set pieces at times. The up close battles are especially well done. Swords, axes and electronic melee weapons all combine to spectacular effect. Dawn of War serves as proof that visualizing a table top game and taking time to develop solid game mechanics and credible army units can pay off.

												A pretty epic RTS. Game-play is balanced (for the most part), introduction of squads and squad upgrades remove a lot of the micromanagement funk while still keeping tactical game-play intact.  All of the races are varied and have different play styles, and not one faction is similar to any other faction. Campaign is decent, but a bit repetitive at times, but still has some pretty memorable moments. Even though it's old, its still visually impressive, and battles are always very entertaining to watch. Great sound design and voice acting too. Like many other Warhammer 40k games, you don't need too much experience with the background in order to enjoy yourself. so if you like RTS games, there is no reason to not pick it up.
