Posted: July 20, 2015
												Worth buying! Entertaining animations, territory control as an actual game mechanic as opposed to a general principle, the expansions add new content but are also stand alone and more or less games in their own right, after you have the expansions the original still seems complete and balanced compared to the sequel DOW II which seems more cash grabesque, quite understandable considering warhammers origins as a tabletop but still; easy to learn but hard to master in the same vein as chess but with more explosions and retreating. That is another thing! Retreating is actually a valid tactic! Make a fallback position to heavy cover when♥♥♥♥♥♥hits fan, beware though that if you turtle in that fantastic invincible making cover your enemy squads can and will spec there squads out with flame throwers and explosives, The wargear mechanic means that while some units are still better than others for specific tasks you can generalize or specialize THOSE units as well! Tanks are scary. Chaos marines flinch easy, Orks splatter, Space marines drown, and Eldar eww.

Posted: July 1, 2014
												Short version? It's still great.Slightly longer version? I played this back in the day and it's still as fresh and fun as ever. You might hear some complaints that the graphics are dated but I disagree. The low poly count and bright textures just add to the feeling that you're playing with animated citadel minuatures. I remember the first time how fun it was to finally see all those wonderful models come to life and start killing each other:) That pleasure hasn't dulled as the animation and audio work is still great. Audio, the one thing that hasn't aged a day. The music is wonderfully atmospheric and fits the characters, the world and the story perfectly. The voice work puts a lot of modern games to shame and makes the relatively simple story really fun to follow.The mechanics of the game keep you on your toes and added an injection of action into the RTS genre. Some complaned it was RTS 'light' but it's simply another twist that helps broarden the genre. When you have hundreds of units all surging into a massive battle, leaving scars on the battlefield and bodies everywhere you're inner child will thank you for giving it a go. (and when you finally get your paws on a squad of Terminators i'd say it was worth every penny)If you have even a passing interest in the Warhammer universe then definately try it. If you enjoy RTS games from back in the day then give it a go. Even if you have a crappy laptop like myself then you can be pretty sure it'll work fine. (I also grabbed the expansions but haven't tried them yet, so I can't tell if they work fine yet)Peace and love

Posted: July 10, 2015
												Note: This game and it's numerous expansions track playtime differently, I have played more than this it is just divided amongst all the expansions which makes playtime harder to truly calculate. Dawn Of War is one of the best RTS games I've ever seen and is definitely worth the purchase and all of it's dlcs, at the time of writing they were all on sale for a combined price lower than 10 dollars, that is an absolute steal. In short, Dawn Of War is an RTS that contains:- 9 Incredibly unique factions ranging from the undead/robotic necron, who do not require requisitions but need to build massive amounts of power to sustain themselves to the legendary Warhammer Space Marines, the super soldiers who define the series with their powerful leadership units and decent unit composition making impossible fights slightly more possible (Though the expansions are needed for 5 of them, by default you get Orks, Chaos Marines, Space Marines, and Eldar though they are pretty unique and can in themselves offer hundreds of hours of gameplay).-Interesting game modes such as the standard destroy the enemy's base ranging to hold various points for a set amount of time or even just slay the enemy commander before yours falls. Plus, you can set more than one victory parameter for maximum gameplay and strategic influence. -Expansions that change the singleplayer experience (Soulstorm and Dark Crusade) to a map takeover in which all of the game's factions wage war and fight numerous matches attacking and defending territory with troops they earned throughout the campaign and even their fation specific commander his/herself.In the end, it is an amazing game well worth your time, though I do suggest getting the expansions as they make the already great game even better.

												Dawn of War is an excellent strategy game, and a must-have for fans of the Warhammer 40,000 franchise. The campaign is solid, the multiplayer and skirmish modes are excellent, and--barring Soulstorm--the expansions are top-notch. Sure, the voice-acting can be corny at times, but then that's part of the game's charm. It's by no means perfect. The AI sometimes has pathing issues, and on occasion there are times were the campaign makes odd choices with some of your units (such as putting the Whirlwind artillery tanks in the Cease Fire stance by default). And of course, there is the mess that is Soulstorm. Even so, I found the game immensely enjoyable for the most part, both as a fan of Warhammer 40k and as a fan of strategy games.

Posted: May 1, 2015
												In 41st Millennium there is only war...Warhammer 40k: Dawn of War was RTS game from the universe developed by Relic. Gameplay is large scale and epic with a mix between base building and managing units. There are two main resources: Power and requisition. Requisition is used to make buildings, units, upgrades. The same can also be said of power, which generates slower. To acquire these resources you need to capture points on the map and hold them. You can field a variety of units including infantry, land vehicles, heroes and super heavy unit. All units cost requisition to make. Upgrades are also available for purchase from buildings. You can upgrade squad with weapons or more members.There are two modes to play with: Campaign and skirmish. Campaign follows Captain Gabriel Angelos of the Blood Ravens chapter of space marines as he faces off against the orc horde. Unlike the latter entries to the series, the campaign is set into levels.  Each level of the campaign starts you off with a few units. Your goal is to build a base and then an army to accomplish various objectives. Such objectives are split between primary and secondary ones and involve either destroying a specific building or enemy unit. Completing all primary objectives will win the level, while secondary ones are optional. Skirmish mode has you face off against up to 7 players/bots in game modes such as annihilation and victory point capture. There are a total of 4 races available to play as including Eldar, Space marines, Orcs and Chaos. The other expansion packs (ie Dark Crusade, Winter Assault, Soulstorm) will allow you to select more races to play as and against, should you acquire them. Audio is excellent. The weapon sound effects feel as they should. Background music fits well with combat. Voice acting for campaign (as units) are well done.If you are looking for a good RTS game with lots of action or you are interested in the 40K universe, this is where to start.

												This game takes what you love about the tabletop (action, strategy, troop management/movement, a killing Orks) and leaves what you don't (spending money). If you are a 40k fan, and also a gamer, there's no reason not to have this game.This is your typical RTS, that utilizes buildings that make infantry, other buildings that make vehicles, and gathering resources (although the resource gathering is much more simplified than in Age of Empires, or even Command and Conquer). Fairly intuitive, this game lets you hop right into the action. You can even "paint" your army and save a custom scheme in case you don't want to ruin the defaults for the different races.This game isn't as in depth as the tabletop as far as the disparity of units. For example, in this game, the Blood Angels have the exact infantry and vehicle choices as the ultramarines. And air vehicles are missing entirely. But still, well done, and true to the source material.I not only recommend this game, but I also bought it and gifted it to a friend so he could play with me. (In multiplayer mode. The campaign is completely single player.)

Posted: July 22, 2015
												Note to myself : rewrite this feedback later, it's unreadable. If you like RTS where your weakest unit can last longer than 1 second and tough units are mean to be tough (they'll last longer than 5 seconds even when things are really intenses, and will win a 1v20 against weak units), then this game is for you. Quite easy to start with (Game Tutorial for beginner), Dawn of War 1 is a classical "build your base, create your army and crush your opponents" game, where you can get both a high amount of units and "Nokia" units (yeah, you won't be able to take them down in less than 10 seconds unless you have enough dakka). The skirmish setting gives you the opportunity to choose between different victory condition (ex : annihilate the enemy, kill the enemy's leader, get enough ressources, ...). If you already played to a Blizzard RTS (Warcraft 3 or Starcraft), you'll discover a new way to get ressources : forget everything about harvesting ressources. Ressources increase automatically : build a Generator, and you'll get Energy over time (+10/sec for each generator, but you'll get 1 energy each 0.1 second). The more you build generator, the faster you'll get Energy (and they'll continue giving ressources, until you or your enemy destroy them). Thus you don't have to worry about "units harvesting ressources" or "exhausting all the map ressources" : just focus on the battle and use your ressources wisely. This game also has memorable ambient music (look out for «Blood Ravens Approach») and nice sync kills too, especially when a heavy unit "crushes" smaller units.Edit : Forgot to mention it, but effectiveness and ineffectiveness (between units) are really applied in this game (a sniper can easily one hit kill an infantry or deal 300 damages to a heavy infantry, but try it out on a building and you'll do less than 20 damages).

Posted: September 21, 2011
												Throwing off the burden of age is hard enough for most games we hold dear without choking on thier own legacy and exposing the flaws we once were willfully ignorant of. But not for this titan of a game which weaves the best mechanics from action and RTS games ensuring freshness combined with timeless fun. Leading the impressive, hulking Blood Ravens proves to be a thrilling experience which excercises a brain that often switches off thanks to overly simplistic modern games. Using the lore of 40K like a paintbrush benefits the game in every regard, the  strong character design of each race to the BRILLIANT voice acting, finishing off with a stimulating, richly composed soundtrack. Being a old school RTS player, the ripping out off micromanagement was a concern unfounded because finding myself as involved with the fates of my units rather then a multitude of speadsheets was a welcome break. Anyone looking fior a fun, enjoyable introduction to RTS, buy this game ASAP.

Posted: March 6, 2015
												This game is fun and relatively easy to learn... so long as you play one of the human factions (the Space Marines and Imperial Guard; Imperial Guard might be in one "Winter Assault" expansion, however). The only problem is the humans are only really capable of fighting either the Orc or "Chaos Space Marine" factions, which have similar fighting capabilities and play styles. One faction, the Eldar, have an annoying ability to jump around the map using "web gates" or "web portals," showing up unexpectedly just about anywhere. If you are playing against the computer, it seems as if the AI knows when your own armies are away from your base, or jump amazing close to your base. This complicates matters because this game is something like "capture the flag," rather than hanging out at your base being a "soccer/football goalie," just defending your structures. To me, this doesn't seem quite fair. All in all, I'd rate this as 4 out of 5 Stars.

Posted: December 21, 2011
												A pretty epic RTS. Game-play is balanced (for the most part), introduction of squads and squad upgrades remove a lot of the micromanagement funk while still keeping tactical game-play intact.  All of the races are varied and have different play styles, and not one faction is similar to any other faction. Campaign is decent, but a bit repetitive at times, but still has some pretty memorable moments. Even though it's old, its still visually impressive, and battles are always very entertaining to watch. Great sound design and voice acting too. Like many other Warhammer 40k games, you don't need too much experience with the background in order to enjoy yourself. so if you like RTS games, there is no reason to not pick it up.

Posted: September 29, 2015
												This is the one that started it all. Winter Assault, Dark Crusade, Soulstorm, it all started here. Even the original Company of Heroes, which was not just better than it's buggy, DLC-bait sequel, but a near-perfect example of an RTS game, was a direct evolution of Dawn of War.All 4 races are actually pretty well-balanced in multiplayer (better-balanced than the source material is nowdays!). The campaign story is great, and fits the Warhammer 40,000 lore perfectly, which makes it a good introduction, if a bit predictable for the already-initiated (if you went in knowing the lore, you knew X was manipulating Y against Z long before the main characters had a clue Z was involved).This came out right when I first started getting into the actual 40k tabletop game, and the original Rome: Total War followed soon after. My 10th-grade GPA could've been a full point higher, but on top of learning 40k and painting my first army, autumn of 2004 was an RTS golden age we will probably never see the like of again.Except here. Why are you still reading these? Go fight for the Emperor and learn to yell "SINDRI!."

Posted: September 30, 2015
												Fun RTS. The squad system with units is interesting how you can equip special weapons. The campaign was excellent with an interesting story and map design, music is fitting to the levels. Good tech tree progression.Didn't outstay its welcome, lasted a fine amount.One mission is bugged, I had the same issue with CD and DVD copies of the game, where you must use arty to kill a base to make your own base, you end up having to kill the base with some jetpack units which is kinda a hassle and you could screw up loosing then and have to restart the level, This is at the beginning of the level so it isn't a hassle if you restart but still.Difficulty wise, very easy. You set up defence in the campaign with 2 - 4 squads starting out then you slowly take over the points and then fortify the points then you steam roll enemy base.Overall, I will give it 7/10 an enjoyable RTS and worth your time. The W40k lore is interesting and kept me going playing the game, I wanted to learn what would happen next.More of a unit based RTS with basebuilding included but not the main point of the game.

Posted: October 7, 2015
												Fun! In a very wierd way....Ths really captures my eye in terms of warhammer games, simply because of the scale of it. On a small map with hundreds of troops absolutely smashing each other, with carnage, death and destruction. The campaign can be a bit unfair at times, but I feel like that adds to how it brings across the "War is hell" feel, even if it is really entertaining to watch loads of tiny gretchens being slaughtered. Some of the time the camera controls can be frustrating. I found myself flying past the troop I wanted to look at at 100 miles an hour, and the camera ould glitch a bit at certain time. Objects in the scenery frequently got in the way of the camera, even when zoomed in fully, and character animations and graphics are pretty janky. (I can forgive that though, this game came out in what, 2005?) Some of the time the animations can be pure eye candy, especially with the Imperial Gaurd's machine factory. Overall this game falls a bit short in some aspects such as controls, but this is really a very small problem. This is a great FUN/10 game, but also has it's much more serious notes in brief, getting straight back to the tactical fighting and troop planning.  8/10.

Posted: January 19, 2014
												I'm not a huge RTS fan (that is to say, I like 'em, but I suck at 'em, :-), but I really liked some of the things they did in this game to enhance tactical gameplay (as opposed to just  the 'BUILD ALL THE THINGS, KILL ALL THE THINGS!' approach used in  AoEII and other games. Units come in squads, you can resupply squads in the field, units shoot without you having to tell them to shoot, capture points, attaching heroes and healers to squads, upgrading. This all made it feel different and exciting and also very much like a Warhammer 40k game (Not a big 40k fan, but WH Fantasy fan, definitely).The story is♥♥♥♥♥♥ the voice acting atrocious, but the gameplay makes up for that. I do have to say I only played the singleplayer campaign (I'm not really into skirmishes and definitely no MP). I liked the inclusion of an Army Painter option in the menu.Will definitely play some expansions and looking forward to DoW2.

Posted: March 6, 2015
												This game is fun and relatively easy to learn... so long as you play one of the human factions (the Space Marines and Imperial Guard; Imperial Guard might be in one "Winter Assault" expansion, however). The only problem is the humans are only really capable of fighting either the Orc or "Chaos Space Marine" factions, which have similar fighting capabilities and play styles. One faction, the Eldar, have an annoying ability to jump around the map using "web gates" or "web portals," showing up unexpectedly just about anywhere. If you are playing against the computer, it seems as if the AI knows when your own armies are away from your base, or jump amazing close to your base. This complicates matters because this game is something like "capture the flag," rather than hanging out at your base being a "soccer/football goalie," just defending your structures. To me, this doesn't seem quite fair. All in all, I'd rate this as 4 out of 5 Stars.

Posted: September 21, 2011
												Throwing off the burden of age is hard enough for most games we hold dear without choking on thier own legacy and exposing the flaws we once were willfully ignorant of. But not for this titan of a game which weaves the best mechanics from action and RTS games ensuring freshness combined with timeless fun. Leading the impressive, hulking Blood Ravens proves to be a thrilling experience which excercises a brain that often switches off thanks to overly simplistic modern games. Using the lore of 40K like a paintbrush benefits the game in every regard, the  strong character design of each race to the BRILLIANT voice acting, finishing off with a stimulating, richly composed soundtrack. Being a old school RTS player, the ripping out off micromanagement was a concern unfounded because finding myself as involved with the fates of my units rather then a multitude of speadsheets was a welcome break. Anyone looking fior a fun, enjoyable introduction to RTS, buy this game ASAP.

If you like RTS where your weakest unit can last longer than 1 second and tough units are mean to be tough (they'll last longer than 5 seconds even when things are really intenses, and will win a 1v20 against weak units), then this game is for you. Quite easy to start with (Game Tutorial for beginner), Dawn of War 1 is a classical "build your base, create your army and crush your opponents" game, where you can get both a high amount of units and "Nokia" units (yeah, you won't be able to take them down in less than 10 seconds unless you have enough dakka). The skirmish setting gives you the opportunity to choose between different victory condition (ex : annihilate the enemy, kill the enemy's leader, get enough ressources, ...). If you already played to a Blizzard RTS (Warcraft 3 or Starcraft), you'll discover a new way to get ressources : forget everything about harvesting ressources. Ressources increase automatically : build a Generator, and you'll get Energy over time (+10/sec for each generator, but you'll get 1 energy each 0.1 second). The more you build generator, the faster you'll get Energy (and they'll continue giving ressources, until you or your enemy destroy them). Thus you don't have to worry about "units harvesting ressources" or "exhausting all the map ressources" : just focus on the battle and use your ressources wisely. This game also has memorable ambient music (look out for «Blood Ravens Approach») and nice sync kills too, especially when a heavy unit "crushes" smaller units.Edit : Forgot to mention it, but effectiveness and ineffectiveness (between units) are really applied in this game (a sniper can easily one hit kill an infantry or deal 300 damages to a heavy infantry, but try it out on a building and you'll do less than 20 damages).

Posted: August 29, 2015
Pros:+ Solid storyline+ Bug-free+ Classic RTS Gameplay+ Clever use of flags+ This is our land now+ But do you have a flag?+ Great Multiplayer/matchmakingCons:- Game is a bit short; single-player campaign lasts roughly 20 hours- Only four playable races; later expansions add moreOverall: Warhammer 40k is a fantastic board game franchise, but it's very expensive.  This is a solid introduction to the world in a fun, entertaining package.  If you played this game in its heyday, you really don't need me to tell you it's great.  If you're new, then know that this game stands the test of time, and is still fun so many years later.  It nails the RTS genre, and still looks good.  It plays smoothly, and rewards clever gameplay and tactics.  The later expansions give more campaigns and more opportunities for multiplayer shenanigans, but this game started it all.Bottom Line: Worth playing and replaying, for old and new fans.  Familiarity with the Warhammer universe not required.

Posted: August 13, 2015
												A decent tabletop to video game conversion. Age of Empires II attempted to use in-game dialogue to simulate real time discussions and events between people in RTS games, but Dawn of War manages to make it even more believeable with the closer camera and the more dynamic movements of the models. The story is riveting, suspensful and startling towards the end. Anyone who enjoys a futuristic crusade and a struggle between good and evil should certainly follow this chronicle. The add-on system of weapons, unit commanders and special attacks enhance the game play in a variety of ways. A menagerie of units is available to not only the Imperium, but the Orks and the Forces of Choas. The map design is very good and the structures are both impressive and fearsome sights. The voice over work is very theatrical and the cut scenes strongly resemble stage set pieces at times. The up close battles are especially well done. Swords, axes and electronic melee weapons all combine to spectacular effect. Dawn of War serves as proof that visualizing a table top game and taking time to develop solid game mechanics and credible army units can pay off.

												This is the first RTS I have played in several years, and the first Warhammer game I have ever played. After finishing the campaign in 14 hours and playing a bit of team based multiplayer with a few of my friends I have come to the conclusion that this game is at least a 9/10 The Warhammer 40k world is a richly expansive universe of the same quality as other such giants in the industry such as Starcraft and Warcraft. All characters are loveable, interesting, and at least memorable. Running into battle with a group of fully upgraded space marines against an opposing force is uplifting as it is intense and exciting. I tend to prefer RPG's and tactical shooters, but Dawn of War is a game that everyone should play at least once. As I can honestly say that after finishing the campaign mode I am now obsessed with the universe and have been doing everything in my power to learn more about it. Do yourself a favor and purchase this gorgeous gem of a game.

Posted: July 7, 2016
												An overall solid RTS that blends the building management, unique factions, and interface of War Craft with the company structures of Kohan. The story for the campaign is also very solid. Even if you aren't thoroughly familiar with the 40k universe (I'm not), it is easy enough to grasp, relying on familiar tropes and simply gift wrapping them with the flavor of the setting. Though you should be warned that it is certainly a product of its time as the hotkey layout is not user friendly (and at the time of this writing the manual doesn't even work). It is also possible that it is not fully compatible with modern operating systems. Several times while playing the screen would get stuck scrolling and the only way to stop it would be to click the minimap. Above all the pathfinding AI is pretty horrible. Units will often stop outside of combat or try to spread out as much as possible with undesired consequences.

Posted: December 14, 2012
												I played Company of Heroes before I started Dawn of War, and I absolutely love both games. Disregarding the several very awesome standalone expansions to Dawn of War, I have to say the original is ♥♥♥♥ing kickass. When I first picked it up, I played it for the classic skirmish option, and set up my own custom games against the AI so I could have massive battles within this awesome universe. But when I really got sucked into this game was when I fired up the campaign with the nice little story, for an RTS game, and the varied missions that escalated the scale and availability of troops as I progressed. If you like RTS games, then Dawn of War is a must-buy. And I would even recommend it to those who've never played an RTS game before because it's very accessible given the less complicated base-building and resource system (no gatherer units, you just build energy generators with workers and capture points with infantry). I often have a difficult time playing the likes of Age of Empires and other games of a similar vein because I'm too lazy to manage everything economy after playing this game.

												A pretty epic RTS. Game-play is balanced (for the most part), introduction of squads and squad upgrades remove a lot of the micromanagement funk while still keeping tactical game-play intact.  All of the races are varied and have different play styles, and not one faction is similar to any other faction. Campaign is decent, but a bit repetitive at times, but still has some pretty memorable moments. Even though it's old, its still visually impressive, and battles are always very entertaining to watch. Great sound design and voice acting too. Like many other Warhammer 40k games, you don't need too much experience with the background in order to enjoy yourself. so if you like RTS games, there is no reason to not pick it up.

Posted: January 28, 2016
												The beta period for Dawn of War was one of my favorite gaming experiences ever. Believe it or not, there was a pretty long period of time where the general tone of gamers online wasn't overtly negative and troll-ish, and the whole beta was filled with fantastic players who were down to play this new and exciting entry into the RTS lexicon.That being said, Dawn of War has certainly aged strangely. Since it has been out for nearly twelve years at this point, its kind of a funky game. Video games have grown up and changed a lot since this was new, but that doesn't really detract very much from the overall experience. Widescreen doesn't really work and isn't worth trying to get to work, as a sidenote.The core gameplay is based more around controlling squads of units than building a base. There are still resource nodes to grab on the map, and you still need to be mindful of the tech tree and working towards better units, but most of the game is army and unit based. Each of the races in the game sort of play similarly, with similar ideas, although some asymmetrical aspects are present. The core design is still fun years later, and games versus the AI can be hectic. If you have a buddy who is down to do some 2vAI games, and you don't mind clunky early 2000's interfaces, you'll get some good mileage out of this. The campaign is totally forgettable and only features one race, though. Online seemed to be a ghost town when I tried it out, but that also might be a side effect of the confusing naming of the first Dawn of War game + expansions.You see, the GOTY edition doesn't contain everything, strangely enough. You're still missing the expansions. If you want the complete experience, you'll have to look elsewhere and get the Platinum edition. I got this through a bundle, so I'm not too miffed, but the naming is confusing.Overall, this was a good bit of time for some nostalgia. I had a blast playing a couple of maps and doing most of the campaign, but there isn't much staying power here if you're not a returning player. You might find the design a bit flawed overall, and there are later Dawn of War games that improved on the formula this game established.

Posted: March 30, 2016
												This strategy game is fairly good for its age (12 years now as for 2016!).The player can play campaign or skirmish. In campaign mode we have 11 missions connected by some pretty average story. Missions are solid for a scripted campaign, although the enemy is just standing there most of the times. Oh yes, the race is Space Marines Blood Ravens chapter if it means anything.When it comes to skirmish we have four races in the base game:- Space Marines- Chaos - Orks- EldarsThe main point of the game, besides destroying enemies that is, is obtaining and keeping requisition points that provide well, requisition points needed to build units and buildings. Be prepared to fight fiercely for those points as it is easy to lose them but it takes a bit too long to re-obtain them.Pros:- 40k mood- pace is fine by me- music is ok- vehicles are really powerfulCons:- infantry battles are a bit too long - what are those bolter loaded with, peebles?- playing tag when it comes to requisition points- graphics are pretty rough around the edges now- most units are slowOverall I've found this game amusing. Campaign mode was fun, though a bit weak on the plot side (Bale & Sindri seemed like Flip & Flap sometimes). I didn't played many skirmishes really, so I can't tell whether this option is good or not. Dawn of War is fun if you like 40k franchise. If not then there are some better RTS games out there.---------- For anyone interested in joining in on completing your own backlog; check it out here - http://steamcommunity.com/groups/completingthebacklog/discussions/5/530645446320364338/

Posted: February 18, 2016
												Damn I love this game ! Having played the Warhammer FPS a few years ago I was attracted to this after playing another Relic game the Company of Heroes series. I've never played the Warhammer table top game but I've at least been in a Games Workshop shop and briefly toyed with board and dice role playing games many years ago. I would guess that some of the developers have played table top RPG's before as some of the kind of humour in that world comes across in this game. I would highly recommend this over Dawn of War 2 as the second game just does not have the same attention to detail, art and graphic design direction that this game has. But DAW2 is a very different game. Here we have Relics calssic attention to detail. The animations and voice acting are incredibly endearing just as we would see a few years later in the first Company of Heroes game. The map design is also solid and believable, where, again, in the second game map objects have been placed badly and you don't feel like your're in a real place.  The sound is also very good. I was listening to a tank firing and it sounded impressive with the shell whooshing off and then a huge explosion as it detonated echoeing off into the map. Sadly that is just not there in DAW 2 although Relic would go on to get it right again in COH2. So well recommended. An excellent diversion and just a very good game.

Posted: August 13, 2015
												A decent tabletop to video game conversion. Age of Empires II attempted to use in-game dialogue to simulate real time discussions and events between people in RTS games, but Dawn of War manages to make it even more believeable with the closer camera and the more dynamic movements of the models. The story is riveting, suspensful and startling towards the end. Anyone who enjoys a futuristic crusade and a struggle between good and evil should certainly follow this chronicle. The add-on system of weapons, unit commanders and special attacks enhance the game play in a variety of ways. A menagerie of units is available to not only the Imperium, but the Orks and the Forces of Choas. The map design is very good and the structures are both impressive and fearsome sights. The voice over work is very theatrical and the cut scenes strongly resemble stage set pieces at times. The up close battles are especially well done. Swords, axes and electronic melee weapons all combine to spectacular effect. Dawn of War serves as proof that visualizing a table top game and taking time to develop solid game mechanics and credible army units can pay off.

Posted: August 4, 2015
												The Gold Edition of Dawn of War was one of the first M-rated games I bought as a teenager, and I always had fond memories of it because it catered to my personal favorite combat strategy: turtling. Nine years later, those feelings are still going strong.For the uninitiated, turtling is the notion of erecting a stiff defensive perimeter, absorbing enemy attacks while establishing one's own economy, then lashing out with the full fury of one's tech tree and crushing the enemy in a swift show of force. Dawn of War's most effective strategy is what I like to call "Turbo Turtle" because of its resource mechanics. Unlike most games which require players to harvest resources from the game world in something of a parallel operation to the military stuff, the two mix together in the form of requisition, gained automatically from capturing various points around the map. This system keeps the game moving because no resource infrastructure is required to build infantry units. Just take a squad or two, capture some points, and you're off and rolling. These points can even have fortifications built on them, keepinig enemies at bay long enough for a force away from the flashpoint to react and engage and allowing the player to hold large swathes of territory (and resources) without desperately trying to get every detail just so to prevent exploits in the defense. (The other resource, power, is produced entirely within the tech tree with bonus areas available on most maps, meaning any shortage is usually self-created.) This keeps the game moving at a reasonable pace and prevents players from turtling for 20-30 minutes while advancing to the next tech level like one might in other RTS titles. This simplified approach keeps the focus on combat and battle tactics rather than letting resource gathering linger in the back of the player's mind.The game also doesn't have players building infantry units piecemeal; instead, infantry come in squads which can be expanded and outfitted with heavy weaponry. The Space Marines - the sole faction the player uses in the campaign - have such powerful infantry that most early missions and even skirmish games can be won with 4-5 decked out squads of their mainline infantry, and the squad as the base unit can result in infantry combat on a massive scale at the climax of a battle. Five full squads of Space Marines puts 45 units under the player's control; mainline infantry for the other races churns out even more individuals, and it's all commanded at the squad level, so, again, no micromanagement.The visuals were quite good for the time, although they haven't held up very well in the nine years since the game's original release. The upside to this is a lack of lag or chug on most modern PCs, even when the battles reach their most frenzied. There are fewer positives to be found with the story (quite dull and rather predictable) and the sound design (the voice acting is downright painful at times), but playing an RTS for the story is like eating a cheeseburger for the pickles; it's nice to have the extra flavor, but it's not really why you bought the burger.Relic hit a home run with this game. Not only did they capture the essence of Warhammer 40,000 and its lore, they also made it something players new to 40k will be interested in and enjoy without getting bogged down in trying to bring 40k's rules to a video game, something other GW-inspired titles (read: Blood Bowl) could stand to learn from. Fun is the most important element of any game, and Dawn of War provides plenty of it. For the Emprah!

Posted: July 1, 2016
												In some ways, Dawn of War hasn't aged all that well. It feels like I'm playing a game on low settings even with everything maxed out, and there's certain UI elements that are missing or hidden, such as hotkeys or a squad tab.But it's important to remember this is a ten year old game; look past the creaking joints, and at the core is still one of the finest 40K games ever made.The core gameplay remains solid and enjoyable, and the campaign is as satisfying as I remember. The plot is solid, with twists and turns as four factions vie for control of the world, and while the narrative plays its hand a bit too early with some of the big twists, it's not enough to spoil the impact.Dawn of War; come for the nostalgia, stay for an RTS experience that's as enjoyable today as it ever was.

Posted: June 28, 2016
												Being a first time RTS player and new, yet deeply interested in the Warhammer franchise after playing Space Marine I decided to grab this game off the Summer Sale and give it a go. I'm mainly gonna focus on the single player aspect of the game as I have yet to get into a multiplayer match (it's quite dead). However, I can say for certain that this game is very fun and enjoyable. It was easy to pick up and get into, the vehicles were fun to mess around with, and building up a large army to use it in a massive assault against the enemy's bases was incredibly satisfying, even if it was just vs AI. The story didn't do much to grip you in the beginng, but later it became quite interesting, maybe a quater of the way through. All in all, highly enjoyable and would recommend to anyone.

Posted: July 7, 2016
												An overall solid RTS that blends the building management, unique factions, and interface of War Craft with the company structures of Kohan. The story for the campaign is also very solid. Even if you aren't thoroughly familiar with the 40k universe (I'm not), it is easy enough to grasp, relying on familiar tropes and simply gift wrapping them with the flavor of the setting. Though you should be warned that it is certainly a product of its time as the hotkey layout is not user friendly (and at the time of this writing the manual doesn't even work). It is also possible that it is not fully compatible with modern operating systems. Several times while playing the screen would get stuck scrolling and the only way to stop it would be to click the minimap. Above all the pathfinding AI is pretty horrible. Units will often stop outside of combat or try to spread out as much as possible with undesired consequences.

Posted: March 28
												Greetings!I make it no secret that the Dawn of War series is my favorite RTS (one could argue the later ones are more rpg) series, StarCraft coming close second and followed by the Command & Conquer.  …I think I just named all the big RTS series out there to begin with so that may have just been mute.  Regardless, it’s a great game though struggles to remain relevant due to some quality of life and less than stellar story.Respect Your Elders:  I really enjoy this game and it shows an amazing stepping stone from early RPGs, yes I’ll easily admit it doesn’t hold up as well as I’d like.  The bare game (without mods) is from a previous generation in both graphics and functionality.  It has most of the quality of life components you’d expect:  Shift Clicking, Queuing Orders, etc but lacks a lot of the expected polish, especially in the realm of pathing.  In many ways this game was the cornerstone of future amazing RTSs.Some Assembly Required:  The game really needs certain mods installed to work correctly, specifically the zoom out mod and the higher screen resolution mod (both of which can be easily found via google) but once these are installed the game runs just as well and is just as fun that I remember.  Another thing that adds to this game (including the rest of the series) is a massive quantity of mods provided by the community, from Grey Knights to Tyranids and new campaigns you can find it all.  Though not as numerous as games like Fallout there is much here to provide years of content.I’m not here to tell you a story:  To be fair the story isn’t all that amazing, it’s more of the cliché ‘kill the enemies attacking you only to find that other enemies are there as well but oh! I got backstabbed by my best friend’ kind of story and the book isn’t terribly better either.  With that said, it does get the job done and is more or less on par with a lot of other RTS games out there.  It doesn’t hold a candle to the story in DOW2 or SC (period) but it is enjoyable and begins a long narrative for the sequel to expand on.Overall, this game is highly recommended, though it may not hold up to modern standards I greatly enjoy the game and feel that it continues to live up to and (with mods) keeps pace with the modern RTSs out there.  I’d argue it is one of the greats and a game that I constantly go back to every year or so.  Highly recommend this game.

This game plays nothing like the original and it focuses on how the group as individuals rather than as a massive body counts in the originals. At first, I absolutley hated this idea and I didn't play it. I got bored and decided to play them as thier own game. Eventually, I felt stupid it was to hate this game for not being like the original. Mainly because this game is awesome to play and customize your characters. Chaos Rising is a shorter game but it is nice that you can use your old save for a new game. Plus, you get to use all your old gear. I had a lot of fun playing it and by this time I got so used to the new play style that I could really appreciate this for what it is. I would recoommend it to people that love Warhammer 40K and the lore around it. Blood Ravens are one of my favorite chapters and to play a game with them in it like this was awesome.

Posted: April 25, 2015
												To start: I used to add a much longer header to these reviews, but since it often made the reviews too long to submit, I've opted to leave it on my Backloggery.Gameplay: One thing that's very difficult not to do when talking about any base-building RTS, let alone a military Sci-Fi RTS, is to not compare it to Starcraft, especially considering the influence that the Warhammer 40k world present in Starcraft. After all, there's a race of humans kinda like the Terrans, there's an alien race like the Protoss, and while not present in this game, there is a race similar to the Zerg. Also much like Starcraft, the gameplay is centered around building bases.The differences come in, as you might expect, with the gameplay. While this is something of a personal taste, I really do quite like how resources are handled in this game. Your two basic resources are Requisition (kinda like Minerals) and Power (kinda like Vespene). You gain requisition from controlling Strategic Points on the map. It is also from these Strategic Points that you build your base, from which you can build in a radius that expands up to a certain point. Unlike Starcraft, you gain resources at a set rate per minute, which is slow enough to require you to think about what you wanna build, as opposed to spamming harvesters all day. Power is gained from building generators, and much like Requisition, is gained at a set rate per minute. There are also Slag Deposits on some maps, which you can capture and build a special generator on, allowing a bit more strategy with your expansion.Units are produced in squads, and vehicles have their own unit cap outside of the squad unit cap. With some research, you can increase your squad cap to 20, and your vehicle cap to 10. While this doesn't sound like much, keep in mind that each squad can have up to ten people in it, reaching Starcraft's famous 200 unit limit very easily, and surpassing it with vehicle count. I do wish that your construction units didn't count as one squad, which can be especially obnoxious as there is no way of recalling your construction units other than sending them out to maybe punch the enemy's base or something.While the game doesn't necessarily have as many units as Starcraft, the matter of unit composition is largely handled by equipment. Your basic squad can be outfitted with four different special weapons, of which each squad can have up to four specially equipped members. Another aspect to this game is its Morale system, in which you can use particularly gruesome attacks to break apart squads, leaving them easy for the pickings as well as discouraging some easy rushes from time to time. The single player campaign is somewhat disappointing, as it only features the Space Marines. I'll talk more about the story later, but for now know that there aren't Eldar, Ork or Chaos Marine campaigns (Eldar being the kinda-Protoss race and Necron being the unlisted kinda-Zerg race). There are apparently campaigns in the expansions, but since I haven't played them yet, I can't speak for them.Now, we come to the important question: how fun is the game? This was my first "legit" introduction to the Real-Time Strategy genre, and I gotta say; I picked a damn good game to start out with. The gameplay is very streamlined, there's usually a great bit of action going on at any one time, and the mechanics are simple enough on the surface while still having a good bit of depth to it for people to play for quite some time. If you're looking for an RTS to get someone's feet wet with, I can very easily recommend this one over Starcraft (although Starcraft may take a bit of weening into) for first timers to the genre. Simple on the surface, deep underneath, very streamlined and just overall a hell of a lot of fun to play. 9/10.Story: Since the completion of this game, I've gone on and read some more of the Warhammer 40k lore, and I've gotta be honest; the campaign doesn't do the series justice. The content is kinda neat, and the Orks are still fun to watch bumble about, but for the Space Marines, this game doesn't do very good in showcasing just how grand their empire is. It feels kinda... fanfic-y, in a not so great way. They try to do some intrigue, but it just doesn't work, and the cliffhanger at the end is, to be quite frank, inexcusable. While the dialogue and writing in-game is good, the actual story itself just isn't good. At all. Disappointing. 6/10.Graphics: Unfortunately, to get this game to run at 1080p I had to download some modded files, which may trigger anti-cheat protection if you happen to play multiplayer. Also, running these files breaks the HUD for the Space Marines (although strangely not for any of the other races). It's frustrating, and I really would expect Sega to get around to making 1080p available in-game without any modding required. Despite this, the game looks pretty good for a 2004 game. Unit design is pretty neat, most of the areas that you visit throughout the campaign look really cool, and of course, seeing an Ork mech tear a Space Marine in half is just plain awesome. I never suffered any frame drops, which is always nice for an older game, as older games around this generation like to depend entirely on your integrated graphics chip if you happen to have one, leaving your GPU idling uselessly. 4.5 for not having 1080p available by default, but the half point comes in because a mod is very easy to download and install.Sound: The voice acting during the cutscenes isn't bad, but it's not exactly award winning work either. Voice acting in battle is pretty good, though, especially for the Orks (I may also have a bit of an Ork bias). The music is pretty excellent as well, and is definitely memorable. It's pretty much entirely orchestral, but it's very "heavy," with loads of brass and percussion; just the way I like my orchestras. Apart from that, there's not much else to talk about here. Good stuff. 4/5.Overall scores are: 9/6/4.5/4; cumulative score of 7.8/10. Again, the biggest problem with the game is the campaign being kinda not good, but at least skirmishing is a lot of fun. Still though, the campaign is disappointing, especially considering that Relic made Homeworld.

Posted: March 6, 2015
												This game is fun and relatively easy to learn... so long as you play one of the human factions (the Space Marines and Imperial Guard; Imperial Guard might be in one "Winter Assault" expansion, however). The only problem is the humans are only really capable of fighting either the Orc or "Chaos Space Marine" factions, which have similar fighting capabilities and play styles. One faction, the Eldar, have an annoying ability to jump around the map using "web gates" or "web portals," showing up unexpectedly just about anywhere. If you are playing against the computer, it seems as if the AI knows when your own armies are away from your base, or jump amazing close to your base. This complicates matters because this game is something like "capture the flag," rather than hanging out at your base being a "soccer/football goalie," just defending your structures. To me, this doesn't seem quite fair. All in all, I'd rate this as 4 out of 5 Stars.

Posted: November 25, 2016
												Dawn of War is by far one of (if not the) the most successful Warhammer 40,000 games to have ever been created- and for good reason. With a great campaign for both the base game and it's first two expansions, Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War - Game of the Year Edition is well worth the price to pick it up (though I recommend buying the Master Collection instead for access to Dark Crusade and Soulstorm). Just don't play Soulstorm first: The expansion is flawed in it's campaign to the extent of madness.

Posted: November 26, 2016
												I've been playing DoW for the past few years and I keep going back to it time and again. It's probably not the best RTS but it works brilliantly within the context of the WH40K universe and it is one of the most consistently fun games I've ever played. Just hearing the Orc scream of 'WAAAAGH' and the pious words of the Emperor's faithful Space Marines are enough to make this game one of my favourite 40K experiences. It's very different from the tabletop vesion but it still has a great deal to offer players, in terms of different races and the iconography of the rich 40K universe, and deserves to be seen as a game which has stood the 'Test of Time'.

Posted: November 27, 2016
												Without this game, we woulden't have had most/all the Warhammer games (espically the Dawn of war series). I wouldn't be able to play  dawn of war, space marine, nothing if it weren't for this game. The Warhammer (40K) series wouldn't have seen as much attention without it, and I know for a fact I wouldn't even know about Warhammer if not for this game.

Posted: January 17
												For a game that is so old its still pretty good... 8/10 !

Posted: January 28
												Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War is in my opinion the best RTS game of all time, and it is just fantastic.Story:- I don't know that much of the Warhammer lore, but as far as I know, it follows it really well. If it doesn't, it still delivers a good and satisfying story!Gameplay:- The gameplay is where this game shines, with different races to play as on over 30 maps, this game never gets old. All races have the same basics, but late game it changes. I won't spoil anything of it, because I think everyone who is a fan of the genre or a fan of the Warhammer universe should play this. There are, as said above, over 30 maps to play on, and all of them are different in some way. Every map is challenging to master, and it adds brilliantly to the replay value and enjoyment.Graphics:- Graphics don't add anything to the overall enjoyment of the game in my opinion, and it doesn't do that here either. The graphics were great for their time, and though the textures definitely look dated, they do hold up over 12 years after its official release.Verdict:Dawn of War is the definitive RTS experience, and it is definitely worth the money, though if you're after graphics, you should probably go for Sins Of The Solar Empire. The game gets a 8/10 from me.- Denolact

Posted: January 18
												Played this game back in the day. One the best RTS games, many reviewers say. Only thing is, this game's engine is the same one from Warcraft 3. And some unit animations are just copy pasted. Also, if you listen carefully, many of the voice actors from Warcraft 3 are present in this game too. Other than that, the game is good and a lot of funn especially with friends.

Posted: January 22
												A must have for any RTS player who likes building army's with basebuilding, this time u can even paint and logo your own army and banners.The resource collection and economy works different, u capture 3 diffrent type of points, most are requisition points, one power and one relic is all u need. most armys will get lets say their main income from requisition points except the necrons as far as i know, for them, power is the main income.power works different as well, it also works as income, so the more u build or the more power points u take the more income of '' power '' u get.u spend requisition and power on buildings and units / expanding units and on upgrades.and the last one, relic points are one for each player in the map, capturing this will grand access to lets say the superweapon unit and the elite units of your army.all points can be defended by building outpost on them and upgrading them, except power points, u need to build around them to defend them.so that is basicly how it works and its more easy then it sounds really.there are tons of races, units and buildings and tons of upgrades, when u think u are done and upgrade your main, everything has upgrades again.painting your own army and giving them logo's and creating your own banner is also unique to dawn of war.every race plays different in building and in army.all the expansions and the original have great campaings two of them have a risk like campaign map with some ingame cinematics.9/10 cant with for dawn of war 3 wich will come out this year.
